38861564.review:
A cute Point and Click adventure that I would totally recommend. It was short (6-7 hours until completed), but longer than I expected from the first look.  
While the characters seem simply illustrated, the world and background is in fact quite detailed and charming, while still making it simple enough to find all the objects you can interact with.

The game draws up its very own world with quirky characters and unique creatures. I was really drawn in by all the details and listened to almost all dialogs to get to know about them. The world and the story kept me immersed, captivated and engaged enough to play through in only a few sessions. The game has great humour in the dialogs and interaction, which makes it just so much more fun and worth exploring all the possible conversations. I had myself chuckling at the screen on so many occasions.
Also, the voice acting is great and well paced. While in other games I find myself skipping a lot of the dialog, I listened to most of it here, as it wasn't too slow or long and brings the characters to life in such a great way. If you wanted though, you could skip every dialog and cutscene. 

The difficulty level isn't exactly easy, but the interactions and combinations mostly make sense (unlike other point & click adventures) and there's no need to randomly combine things. If you do get stuck, there's quite a good hint system that helps you out by giving you information in little pieces, trying not to spoil anything. 

I found the story interesting with a few surprises, not very obvious. That being said, I would have loved a more thorough ending.
Also, in conversations you can talk about a single topic several times. I clicked on all of them, because I wanted to explore all the conversation and not miss anything, but often they keep blabbering about the same topic without really giving more content. 

I also liked that you don't have too many scenes at once were you go looking for possible things to do, but I was annoyed at the loading screen between them, which made me really impatient. One scene in particular, where you have to go back and forth a lot had me waiting so often that it kinda took away from the fun.

Also, the achievements aren't very hard to get. If you read the descriptions, you could get almost all of them in a single playthrough. That might spoil some of the story though, so I wouldn't advise it.

38233992.review:
For me it is a 10/10

What a beautiful, amazing, fantastic adventure and point and click game. I adored it from the very start until the breath-taking – and somehow - a bit sorrowful ending. No worries – no spoilers. It is a good story.

The story is eminent in all details. Just eminent. 

It folds out again and again and all of the characters come to life. You really do believe in them as the story unfolds. 
All characters matters. Good or evil.  Because it is a game of good and evil – could it have been anything else?

The graphics are well composed; all of a sudden you notice details that you did not pay attention to earlier. The details may not have anything to do with the story, but it doesn’t matter.
But this is how you can tell that the developers really cared. That the game really mattered to them in all those tiny details. And then it matters to you as well.


Be in for a game with some nut-cracking puzzles – some of them may not make any sense at first, but we will figure it out sooner or later. 
And maybe we will not…

If it is a problem, the game has an amazing hint system: You can ask for a hint – but only a little piece of hint little by little. It is unfolding to the length of your need. Nothing more...
I have played a lot of games in the same genre on Steam and on other platforms, but this is truly the best way of helping the players if they are stuck.


As you can tell, I really enjoyed “The Inner World”. 
Nah: I was carried away to another world, and I wished I could stay there forever. It was one of my best game experiences ever.

I will give it a 10/10, and I am going to play again and maybe again. I might have missed some obscure details… In fact: I know I have…

If you like point and click, well-thought-of voiceovers (sorry I didn’t mention those – they are terrific), lots of surprises, astonishing characters and a good length of a game, you should just buy it. It is AMAZING!

I am looking forward to se more games from the indendant german studio Fizbin.

35565155.review:
The Inner World is a very charming point-n-click adventure game of the Lucasarts variety, where there are no actual failure conditions, and the game can never get into a no-win state.  The Linux port, which is the one I played, is unfortunately pretty awful, but in the end I'd recommend it even on that platform (though see below for specific complaints about the port, and be prepared to hit that Refund button if the workarounds aren't good enough for you).

Back to positives, the puzzles are often quite inventive and unique, while also generally not being overly difficult.  There's some great pervasive humor throughout, a fairly touching (if predictable) story of personal discovery throughout, good background music, and great voice acting!  It's a very nicely self-contained story, and it's a world I'm excited to get back to in the forthcoming sequel.  My only real complaint storywise is that the main villian turns out to have one of those nonsensical "let's just destroy everything for no adequate reason" type motivations, but whatever.  The game is, IMO, well worth your time.

The Linux port, though!  Man.  It's rough.  I actually gave up on trying to play the game a few years ago because I couldn't for the life of me get any of the cutscenes to play, though recently (and on a different distro) I gave it another go and was able to get through the game.  I'm gonna enumerate the issues on the Linux version, so you can judge for yourself whether you're willing to fight through 'em:

[b]1. Cutscene Problems[/b]

Even now that cutscenes in general worked for me, there were many cutscenes which [i]wouldn't[/i] play.  Some of which included vital clues that you'd need to solve puzzles, too, so it wasn't just story you'd be missing out on.  I did figure out solutions for all but two of the game's cutscenes (and the two were pretty minor ones), though, so check out this post for workarounds for those: http://steamcommunity.com/app/251430/discussions/0/611701360817206606/?ctp=3#c1488861734110465332

This problem is, honestly, extremely galling because it gives the impression that the devs/publishers literally never played through the game to completion on Linux, despite offering a Linux version for sale.  It was pretty basic stuff.

[b]2. No Steam Achievements or Playtime notification[/b]

You'll note that my playtime just says "0.6 hours."  I promise you it's much more than that; I've solved the game.  It just doesn't generally talk to steam at all.  Interestingly, I think the only time it DOES record your time properly is when playing cutscenes, since I always get the Steam popup in the corner when one starts.  (The cutscenes, on Linux anyway, always play in a completely new window, which is why that's possible.)

[b]3. Rather broken options menu[/b]

Adjusting the volume sliders is a bizarre and unintuitive combination of frantically clicking around, hitting arrow keys, and occasionally seeing the sliders move around with seemingly little relation to what you're actually doing.

[b]4. Sometimes similarly-broken UI in the game[/b]

Early in the game, for instance, you can climb up on a balcony overlooking the temple.  You have several interaction options up there, but only one of them actually accepts mouse clicks properly.  Later in the game, I noticed that inventory interactions would often choose "Use" when I clicked "Look."  I encountered one place which would reliably seem to cause all game-related input to be ignored for a few tens of seconds before magically starting up again.  In general this didn't pop up too often, though, at least.

[b]5. The bottom-screen inventory hovering doesn't work, nor does "Escape"[/b]

This, at least, has an easy workaround by hitting Tab, but still.  Lame.

[b]6. Background music/noise stops playing if the game loses focus[/b]

This can be regained by hitting <Tab> and then the wrench icon, to bring up the options menu, and then returning to the game.  Sound will resume once you do that.  (It'll also come back on its own after you move to a new room or two.)

[b]7. Sometimes dialog audio doesn't actually play[/b]

I didn't take the time to pin this one down exactly, but there were many points in the game where a dialog line just wouldn't be spoken.  Not a huge deal since it was still onscreen, but still.

[b]8. Cutscenes frequently seem to use the German versions, with German signage, even though the English versions definitely exist in the media dir[/b]

Not a huge deal, obviously.

[b]9. Other more minor bugs:[/b]

There's a weird bug where you can jump ahead to the third section of the game, when you'd just started it.  (Minor spoilers follow) [spoilers]The first time I hit the button on the paper airplane machine in the Root Forest, it showed cutscenes for all three directions and gave me the final result of the last cutscene (which was not the position the machine was in originally).  Also the guard keeping you from the Laboratory and Throne Room, in the Basylian factory hops about 100 pixels to the left after each interaction, sometimes reverting back to his original spot but more often ending up completely off the screen.[/spoilers]

[b](That's all I'll list, I swear)[/b]

Anyway, as you can see, it's [b]not[/b] a good port by any means.  The main problem which makes the game borderline-unplayable is the cutscene issue, which thankfully can be worked around by the methods I describe.  It's a measure of how much I enjoyed the game otherwise that I'm willing to recommend it on Linux [i]despite[/i] all the lack of polish on here.  I'm excited for the sequel but I'm also going to be waiting to hear how the port is before putting my money on it.

34357824.review:
Nice, valuable story, beautiful theme. Seems slightly inspired by Loom.
Game has some bugs from trivial to slightly annoying.
Writing (believability of NPC behavior) is sometimes not perfect, but can easily be forgiven especially in a point&click adventure like this.
Various achievements are missable and if you want to get them all, checking their descriptions can spoil things. Not good. Would have been better to not have any achievements on this, or not like that. (Especially since the game autosaves, so no easy going back later to hunt for achievements.)

As for my puzzle solving experience:
Every segment had a point where I got stuck. Some I eventually figured out by myself, others I lost patience with. The problem: When I was clueless, I just tried using everything with everything and still was stuck because turned out I forgot one thing and that was the solution, hah. Always make sure to talk to NPC every now and then and go back and forth in the world when something changes, any yeah, if you try all combinations, make sure you do it systematically. The puzzles are quite logical, but you can easily look as something and go "No, that's the least likely." although it makes sense; you just don't see it.

32601632.review:
[h1]Eine Reise zum Mittelpunkt der Erde[/h1]

The Inner World ist ein 2D Point-and-Click Adventure des deutschen Spieleentwicklers Studio Fizbin. 

[b]Story:[/b]
In einer sonderbaren Welt lebt  Robert, ein ebenso freundlicher, wie ahnungsloser Novize. Er führt ein beschauliches Leben als Hofmusiker. Dies ändert sich jedoch schlagartig, als die Windbrunnen ihre Dienst versagt und dann auch noch die Windgötter dieses eigentlich so friedliche Land heimsuchen. Die Geschichte um Robert und Asposien ist spannend und zugleich sehr lustig. Besonders  die Dialoge sind genial. Die Geschichte ist aber etwas zu sehr vorhersehbar, große Überraschungen bleiben aus. 

[b]Anspruch:[/b]
Dank eines Hilfesystems ist das Spiel sowohl für geübte Adventurer, als auch für Anfänger hervorragend geeignet. Es gibt keinerlei Frust.

[b]Rätsel:[/b]
Wie jedes Point-and-Click Adventure ist auch The Inner World voller Rätsel. Diese fallen recht abwechslungsreich aus und machen immer Spaß. Einige wenige sind aber einfach nur unlogisch. Man muss viel rumprobieren. Glücklicherweise gibt es ja das Hilfesystem. 

[b]Präsentation:[/b]
The Inner World sieht einfach großartig aus. Die Hintergründe sind komplett handgezeichnet. Auch der Soundtrack passt.

[b]Steuerung:[/b]
Funktioniert prima mit Maus und Tastatur. 

[b]Umfang:[/b]
Leider nur sieben Stunden Spielzeit. Sammelobjekte gibt es keine. Aber immerhin ein paar Errungenschaften.

[b]Preis:[/b]
Fairer Preis. 

[b]Fazit:[/b] 
Qualitativ kommt The Inner World nah an Daedalics Adventure Meisterwerke. Von meiner Seite eine wärmste Empfehlung!

[h1][b]Wertung: 8 von 10 möglichen Punkten.

30804390.review:
In this point-and-click adventure game, you play as Robert, an adorably naive boy in the land of Asposia, an entire society built on the inside of the world rather than on its surface (hence the name of the game). Asposia runs on wind, but only wind fountain out of the original three in Asposia is still functioning, so the lights are going out and the residents will soon suffocate. Also, there are attacks from the wind gods, who petrify anyone deemed "immoral." Robert gets unwillingly pulled along for the ride. It's a great story with some interesting puzzles.

Pros:
+ Great story and worldbuilding. Very unique.
+ Good humor. Robert is adorable and sheltered, leading to some hilarious situations like him not understanding sexual innuendo or is naive enough to believe a holy man when he claims that he's "meditating" while at a slot machine. There are lots of other fun characters, like helpless researchers and blockheaded guards.
+ Decent music. Not super memorable, but good at setting a mood and not intrusive or annoying.

Neutral:
~ Generally fun puzzles, but there were a few that were annoying because they involve combining a bunch of non-related items to solve a puzzle, and it's not obvious what you're making until it's finished. Having the "A-ha!" moment AFTER you've built a thing is definitely the wrong order.

Con:
- Game is a bit buggy. I had a game-breaking bug in the last chapter, but fortunately, there are save game files available in the Steam community for all the chapters. Also, you have to have Adobe Air up to date or the game will freeze after every cut scene.

Overall: 8/10. It's a fun game, and definitely worth a play if you like adventure games.

30244946.review:
"The Inner World" is a point & click adventure from Germany that is suitable for and recommended to beginners and lovers of adventure games.
Its story takes place in Asposia, a world that mostly lives from wind and light but suffers under its dictator Conroy. His adopted son - or should I better say "slave" - is the protagonist and by accident he stumbles out of the palace he has lived all his life and begins an adventure which will make him discover the outside world, love and some (ugly) truths.

This point & click adventure is easy to control and to understand. The way you select your items and go through dialogues (all displayed with symbols) is similar to "Sam & Max: Hit the Road" (thus also playable for illiterates by the way).
So your main task is to progress in the story by talking to characters, finding items and combining them with other things. You can't die in the game or get yourself into dead ends. 
The difficulty level is fine, the puzzles aren't child friendly-easy but also not too hard. However, as in classics like several LucasArts adventures or "Simon the Sorcerer" you definitely need to think laterally a lot in order to progress. So it's still challenging here and there. If you're still stuck, there is an in-game help but I personally don't know if it's good (I never used it).

What makes the game for me is this universe and its culture you're introduced to, the story and its main character. It's a game full of charme and a good dose of humour. However, the further you get the darker the story feels which is also pretty cool. Even though you can't die in the game you experience more and more traces of darkness, dictatorship, superstition and threats in this world. That's when the humour comes handy and brings extra charme to the game. And as for the characters, especially Robert is great here thanks to his naive but optimistic nature, his design and his English voice actor Mike McAlpine.

Speaking of, let's quickly talk about the graphics and sound.
The animations are or are like digital Flash animation. It's not glamourous graphics but the cartoon style is original and likeable, you can connect to those Asposians and the other creatures very well (at least I can). Original is also the character design. The backgrounds look more detailed and not only that, they look beautiful. Also despite of the cartoonish style it's never in too bright colours, the colours are actually quite subtle.
The soundtrack is very nice. So nice though that I purchased the soundtrack DLC after finishing the game. It's beautiful and serves a lot of the game's atmosphere. When it comes to voices you can choose between the German and the English language. Even though the game's from Germany and so am I, I personally prefer the English version. I just like chosen voices there better, especially Robert's voice (as mentioned before).

Are there things I don't like in "The Inner World"? Just a few minor things that never seriously destroy the game. 
There are little flaws in the animation (people who have created vector graphics in general or flash animation may know what I mean). Also I wished that the world of Asposia had at least more background characters. Most of the time it looks like you save a world that's barely populated at all (and yes, I know, why a certain amount of people are gone but still...).

What about extras? Well, there's a "Play Flute-Nose" option in the main menu which allows you to play Robert's nose as a flute à la "Guitar Hero" (react to the music by pressing certain buttons in the right moments). I haven't played this often because it's not that great for me but if you enjoy this kind of music game or a bonus mini game in general, you might like this.
There are also Steam achievements and trading cards. 

So: Do I recommend "The Inner World"? Yes, definitely, if you enjoy adventure games.
Personally I enjoyed it very much. I don't consider this one of the greatest adventures ever but it's still very good and since I know that there's a sequel game coming in summer 2017, I'm so looking forward to it and can't wait to play it.

29700654.review:
[i]The Inner World[/i] is a point & click adventure game. Its [b]story[/b] is set in the fantasy world of Asposia. Asposia is a world surrounded by earth. Air is blown into Asposia through only a few large holes. Each of these holes is guarded by a wind monk. Robert lives in a wind monastery with one of the wind monks. He's treated like a doormat and has never left the monastery. By accident, he plunges through a garbage chute and finds himself in a world he knows very little of. What will he discover?

The [b]graphics[/b] of [i]The Inner World[/i] are hand-drawn and cartoonish in style. The world of Asposia looks pretty nice and full of life. The characters look ugly but that's a style the developers chose. I'm sure they didn't think they created the most beautiful animated characters ever, but they consciously chose a simple, cartoonish look for their characters, which fits the world and the story they wanted to show us.

The game is German in origin but the way it was transitioned to the English version is impressive. This shows in two major ways:
[list]
[*] The [b]voice acting[/b] is top-notch. The voice actor of Robert, the protagonist, manages to capture Robert's innocense and naivety perfectly.
[*] The [b]humour[/b] did not get lost in translation, as is often the case. [i]The Inner World[/i] is even genuinely funny at times. It's not often that a computer game can make me laugh out loud a couple of times, and makes me giggle a few more times on top of that.
[/list]
The [b]difficulty[/b] of [i]The Inner World[/i] is challenging enough but the solutions to the puzzles are always logical, so the game never becomes frustratingly hard and it never makes you want to look up a walkthrough. To help you play through the game more easily, you can hold the mouse button to see all the objects Robert can interact with. Should you find yourself stumped, you can open a help menu and get a hint on what to do next. If you still don't know how to proceed, you can ask to get another hint. And so on, until the solution is pretty much spelled out to you.

[i]The Inner World[/i] has 7 [b]Steam Trading Cards[/b]. You'll get 4 while running the game. Of the 23 [b]Steam Achievements[/b] some are storybound and unmissable, but other achievements are optional and very much missable. These missable achievements show a lot of creativity on the developers' part, as they are often rewarded for trying out alternative solutions or at least experimenting with the items you collect and objects in the environment.

Много ли сейчас хороших квестов, которые уже давно не носят этот ярлык, а именуют себя "адвенчурами" и "поинт энд кликами". Ну, 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐈𝐧𝐧𝐞𝐫 𝐖𝐨𝐫𝐥𝐝, может и не величественный квест, но достоин своего внимания, это точно. 

Меня всегда привлекал этот жанр по многим причинам, одной из которых являлась рисовка, а не компьютерная графика. Это делало их более человечными, несмотря на невозможность фразы. Да и жанр этот заставляет погрузиться в игру, обращая внимание на мелочи, сосредотачиваться и включать логику [i](иногда выключать)[/i]. 

Здесь нет людей, хотя мелькает это слово. Роберт, главный герой этой истории, наивный бедняга, которому предстоит выяснить кучу неприятных вещей о своей жизни и попытаться спасти мир от алчности одного бывшего монаха. И нос его, в отличие от привычных в этом месте носов, вовсе не такой, как у всех и это будет тщательно скрываться. Нет, это игра не про нос, но с ним будет немало возни, уж поверьте. 

Как и в старых, добрых квестах, вы сможете соединять предметы, разъединять их, использовать на себя и на любой объект, на который можно будет кликнуть [i](но сработает ли?)[/i]. Так что, много болтовни по поводу и без гарантировано. Правда, второстепенных персонажей в игре будет не так много, так что это не особо должно вас путать. Но из-за проблемы этого жанра, где здравый смысл уходит на второй план и приходится думать в стиле "я ведь могу поместить это в клей.... приделать к нему.... и дать это..... гениально....". Но сейчас этот жанр сильно упростился, так как герои берут только нужные предметы, а раньше брали все, что попало. И возись потом с этими ненужным хламом, ломая голову. 

𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐈𝐧𝐧𝐞𝐫 𝐖𝐨𝐫𝐥𝐝 хорошая встряска и возможность вспомнить детство. Самый домашний жанр на мой взгляд, который действительно греет душу.

26470798.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
The Inner World is developed by Studio Fizbin and published by Headup Games. Dev team’s first and so far only foray onto Steam. I’d say they managed to offer an interesting game even if it never stands out really.
 
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
It’s a coming-of-age type of story, at least at it’s very beginning. Inner World’s protagonist, is a shy and rather naïve little boy named Robert. He starts this adventure like most video game heroes do, fulfilling errands. A less common element would be that you start by working for the game’s main antagonist. The game’s world, Asposia is a rather intricate fantasy realm in which a force of nature (in our case, wind itself) is used as a leitmotif. For an adventure that is also addressed to younger audiences, Inner World contains satire and pop culture references that will amuse older gamers. As far as its storyline is concerned, this title won’t disappoint. Especially if you’re accustomed to 2D adventures and you can imagine just what sort of odd characters you shall interact with. The other almost classic features of the genre, such as the inventory system and dialogue options are under a familiar interface with the occasional mixing of two components, in order to create another one. 

What I found intriguing was that even wild combinations seem to work and even when they don’t, you still receive an Achievement for trying. A nice touch indeed, from the developers. Story seems long enough, since I’ve only seen a small part of the map so far. A minor complaint from me, would be related to the way all the in-game items you collect seem to blend in so well with the scenery. You really have to keep an eye out for them and click on every little nook and cranny.

The beautiful hand drawn locations and characters clearly show the efforts undertaken by the devs in order to separate from similar titles. And from the artwork perspective, I’d say they accomplished that. Voice acting is more than decent, both in English and in the game’s original language, German. I stuck with English dubs and subs and found no typos or mispronunciations so far. Worth mentioning as well, is the musical score which I found particularly soothing and proper.
 
[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Original storyline, filled with humor
+ Intuitive puzzles and a comprehensive hint system
+ Steam Achievements & Trading Cards

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- A few dialogues tend to drag on, thus slowing the story down
- Items blend in too well with the scenery

[h1]Result / Final thoughts[/h1]
If you’re looking for a good fantasy adventure that won’t strain you too much, you should give The Inner World a chance. Since it targets a large part of the gamer demographic, it’s ideal even for a novice as well as a veteran of this genre. While I’m not exactly okay with its pricing, I do realize that a lot of effort is being placed into such games, from concept art and down to the skilled voice actors.

[b]Rating 7/10[/b]
 
[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/elitegives]Elite Giveaways[/url], check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA titles.[/quote]

25991383.review:
[h1][url=store.steampowered.com/app/251430/]The Inner World[/url] offers an elegantly simple adventure set in a pleasantly peculiar little world. Its immediately charming ambiance and art style lend a unique tone to the reasonably enjoyable story, where every detail is nicely executed but falls short of impressing.[/h1]

Your character, Robert, is strangely charming in his naive and very literal approach to everything. He does not understand metaphors and is relatively dimwitted with a knack for stating the obvious. Your eventual partner has a far more confrontational and action-driven persona. Most characters you'll meet are actually quite original and rather silly.

Decent writing and delightful vocal performances, with strangely slow-paced and very articulated dialogue, make the game actually sort of relaxing to hear. Coupled with the reassuring absence of failure, it is quite pleasant if somewhat unexciting.

The game behaves as you'd expect in a point-and-click, with an overall high level of polish, except in a few scenes where the audio sometimes cut abruptly at inappropriate times. Nice, clean interface, particularly with good iconography used for all dialog choices. Technically very stable.

[h1]"That's just a random guess, isn't it?"[/h1]

Puzzle requirements and solutions unfold naturally, except in the final chapter, which I found a bit more obtuse than the rest. Situations are all a bit absurd but nearly always made sense within the given context. My interest nevertheless progressively dwindled once the novelty wore off and the plot turned into a more conventional cliché.

Funny achievements reward failed creative attempts or silly solutions. One of the better uses of achievements I've seen in any type of game, they complement the humour nicely.

Serviceable but unremarkable cutscenes are directly layered over the background panels for a nice, dynamic integration. The hand-drawn animation has style but the frame rate is not very smooth. Also, English signs do not match spoken dialogue and remain in German during cutscenes, but that's just nitpicking.

If this game were a meal, it'd be the sort that fills you up sufficiently to satisfy the hunger but would not cut the craving for truly delicious food. There's really nothing to dislike about The Inner World. It's a fun, simple game in the tradition of the genre, built on solid foundations that will hopefully spawn a better sequel.

24432742.review:
The Inner World tells the story about a world inside a giant ball of dirt and how the wind stopped blowing as the wind gods grew angry with the world and began to turn people to stone. Their only hope lies in an evil mastermind who bargains with the wind gods daily. When his naive and unassuming apprentice, Robert, accidentally loses his master's pendant, he goes outside of the palace for the first time in his life to find it. What follows is a hilarious, fascinating, and clever point-and-click game about Robert and wanted criminal Laura trying to save the world.

All the basic polish is fanatstic; the music is great and suits the mood perfectly, the art style is superb and excellently captures the essence of the seedy underground you'll be exploring for most of the game. Every character is completely unique, with the exception of the guards, which are supposed to be carbon copies of each other, the dialogue is extremely well-written, and there are underlying themes throughout that are both morbidly fascinating and innocently interesting. The puzzles are extremely clever and intuitive, requiring you to think both outside and inside the box. You may need to collect an arrow not for a knife or weapon, but for the tail that can be used to clean out a pipe.

The games' biggest downfall is its length and pacing. There are only five chapters, and I beat the game in about eight hours with most of the achievments. The way it was set up, with the underlying mysteries, strange minds of the supporting cast, and overall themes, it felt like an adventure that should have lasted at least ten chapters, which would also have left room for some characters to be developed. You only get to play as Laura one time during the entire game, and her snarky comments and conversations were perfect for multiple uses during a game like this. In fact, it almost feels cut off; you accidentally land in the bad guy's lair after falling through a hole in the third chapter, which brings an anticlimactic feel to the whole experience, like you were cheated out of a longer game. Near the end, everything kind of plateaus out; the puzzles are suddenly rather easy, and the end comes up much more quickly than expected. It was, admittedly, a disappointing end to a great game, and makes me want to beg for a sequel where I can properly explore this fascinating world.

In the end, The Inner World is a brilliant little game with clever puzzles and an intriguing story that just ends a little too early. If you like point-and-click adventure titles, don't pass this one up.

23462256.review:
Of the games that I've discovered on Steam so far, this has been by far one of the best. It's vastly amusing, simple yet thoughtful, charming in its graphics and character voicing, and most importantly to me, the puzzles are LOGICAL. After playing Deponia, which was challenging even with a detailed walkthrough, the logical thought pattern of "well, this doesn't hit the bad guy in the jaw like I was hoping, but it is going under his nose, and I happen to have knockout drops, therefore when it passes underneath he will fall unconscious onto the button" is very refreshing. it's nice to be able to figure out some problems on my own before turning to the in-game hints. Those hints, by the way, are super nice because they'll not only give you pointers to the logical procession of seemingly unconnected tasks, but the hints are arranged in a way that you can click through a couple, just enough to get the idea without it expressly telling you, without feeling like you've totally given up on all problem solving on your own.

Robert is a very sweet likeable character, though Laura was a bit of a drag at times. The plot was engaging, and had a few unexpected twists. Very rarely do I get engrossed enough in a game to feel worried or horrified for the characters, but this one sucked me in and I was genuinely rooting for Robert and Laura long before the end.

That being said, I would also recommend this game solely because of the hilarious progression of the Conrad puppet.

A must-have game for those who like a casual point-and-click. And also laughing a little. And mocking Conrad puppets,
10/10

23416947.review: The Inner World is a fantastic game. The production quailty is very high, and  the art direction in particular is superb. The dialogue is witty - often dry and droll or amusingly absurd. The music and sound effects are just perfect, and the characters are relatable, evocative, funny and even adorable. At times the puzzles are a little obscure, but for the most part their solutions are more easily deduced than many games of this type because practical creative problem solving - given the clues and tools at hand - does the trick. If you enjoy humorous, imaginative,  story-driven, and beautifully illustrated point and click adventure games, you'll definitely want to add The Inner World to your collection!

Ich bin äußerst erfahren in adventure games, aber hier war ich meist einfach nur wirklich clueless.
Zum Glück gibt es ein ingame-walkthrough, was aber auch wirklich bitter nötig ist.

Des Weiteren sind die Ladezeiten zwischen den Schauplätzen extrem langwierig und man muss oft einfach immer weiter die location wechseln und das suckt einfach mega hart und man verliert immer weiter die Laune noch am Ball zu bleiben.

Die Dialoge sind bestenfalls zum schmunzeln, alles ist super kindisch und unser Protagonist ist ne Oberweichflöte ... 
das macht die Reise nicht besser sondern einfach immernur dämlicher.
Ich hab das game glaub ich für 5-7 € gekriegt, was den entwicklern aufjedenfall gegönnt sein soll, aber du solltest dich fragen, willst du wirklich ein spiel kaufen, dass du vermutlich niemals finishen wirst?

Suchst du ein fettes adventure was richtig hart zu knacken und alles hat was man heutzutage erwartet mit einer story die du unbedingt durchzocken möchtest? 

Randals Monday !!!

23042847.review:
What a delightful game! It's quirky and full of fun characters and moments, and though I was left stumped a few times, when I ran out of ideas (or patience) the game itself provided a hint system that did its best not to give you the answer straight out, but to gently coax you in the thought pattern they intended. It was also a nostalgic trip for me, since I've grown up on point-and-click adventure games, like the fabled Quest for Glory series and the King's Quest series, but crafted in such a way that made it delightfully modern and fresh. 
Also, what fantastic voice acting! Robert's voice is incredibly easy on the ears, and I loved all of the commentary from both him and Laura. 
One of the other things that I truly loved was to see Robert's own journey - having the courage to escape from the only home he'd ever known, and then to face the truth of his surrogate father being a terrible monster (not really a spoiler, since you can tell right away that he's not a good person at all), all the while never losing his gentle spirit. In fact, his kindness, polite demeanor, steadfastness in the face of adversity, and humility were the things I most loved about him.
I do hope there will be a sequel - I'd love to spend more time in Asposia and get to explore the world more!

22819711.review:
This brought back the fun, interesting dialogue, characters and stories of old Point and Click adventure games and gave me a healthy dose of nostaliga and was a real joy to play. It's just a shame it's so damn short compared to the titles I remember from the older days.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]

The writing, characters, world and art-style are all important things for Point & Clicks, and The Inner World gets all of them right. Due to the short length of the game the characters don't really develop, but they mostly have enough backstory and care of writing to have more than one dimension. They all have reasons for doing what they're doing and even short interactions like helping the character involve a motivation of some kind that you don't see written into too many games these days.
The world is rich and interesting and again, thought and care and good writing have gone hand in hand to create a diverse landscape with enough character to feel immersive. The art-style is friendly but layered enough to add time and history, and importance where it's due.

[h1]Mistakes and Annoyances[/h1]

My biggest complaint with The Inner World is the short length and lack of content. Although it's well written and shines as an upbeat story, with only 3 memorable characters and a couple of protagonists and a handful of areas it just doesn't have enough content to explore and ultimately feels rather shallow. As a result it's good value for money when on sale, but is hard to recommend at full price because of the low level of content to explore.

Some may find this far too easy, and at times I think it feels a little too casual, as though you're merely exploring an interactive artbook rather than solving puzzles and furthering the story with gameplay, but these moments are sparse and unless you have a hard time investing in the story or characters, or don't enjoy the writing then you'll find plenty of joy in just exploring what's here, nevermind solving the puzzles.

Other than that The Inner World really doesn't have anything to criticise. There are a couple of sections where it's not particularly intuitive on how to progress, and the age old Point-and-Click problem of disjointed solutions becomes apparant, but these are mitigated by the wonderful hint system and become easy to overlook.
Perhaps you could complain the small extra content game unlocked after playing isn't fun and essentially pointless, but that's hardly a compelling reason against buying the game.

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]

Priced on Steam at £11.99/$14.99/13.99€, The Inner World clocks in at a typical 7-8 hours of gameplay, and has enough charm and dimensions to warrant an additional playthrough or two down the line. It's very fairly priced if you don't mind the short length and goes on sale for up to 85% off, which is a bloody bargain.

* An animated series based on the game is/was planned, a demo of which is available here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=STsqPrG8L7E
* Funding for a sequel, The Inner World 2 - The last Windmonk, seems to have been approved in 2015 as mentioned in [url=http://innovation.mfg.de/de/standort/kreativwirtschaft/games/digital-content-funding-ein-wiedersehen-mit-den-flotennasen-1.38522]this German press release[/url]

22617075.review:
出乎所有的想象，世上有一片完全由土壤构成的空间。在这个空间的深处，有一个广阔的球状世界，这个世界中的人将它称作“艾斯波西亚”。三个神圣的凤泉维持着这个世界空气的流通。至今，对于风的来源，人们仍众说纷纭。不过，不可否认的是，这里的风正在一点一点的枯竭。没有风，就没有光。没有光，就没有温暖。风神就在这片冰冷的黑暗中翩然而至。自此他们和他们那石化的目光便成了艾斯波西亚人的梦魇。


　　故事由此开始。

[h1] 短小精湛的故事[/h1]

　　以游戏片头的这段介绍来开始我们艾斯波西亚之旅吧。故事开始于风神——巴塞里安袭击而来的１５年后。艾斯波西亚风光不再，作为重要的动力来源的三个风泉全数枯竭。大街上、甚至是酒馆里，到处都有石化了的艾斯波西亚人，人们人心惶惶，守卫玩忽职守。某一天，不知从哪里突然飞来了一只鸽子，它居然吞下了三大风之守卫的其中一人——康罗伊最重视的吊饰！身为康罗伊视如己出的学徒——罗伯特自然不能坐视不管了，他毫不犹豫地跳下了垃圾输送管道追了上去。不久后，他就遇到了鸽子的主人，漂亮的少女劳拉，从来没见过异性的罗伯特一眼就被她所吸引，从此展开了两人的冒险之旅。

　　游戏时长并不是很长，包含的信息量却不少。在短短的五章里，我们会了解到１５年前那起事件的真相、罗伯特的身世之谜，风泉之所以会起风的秘密，不为人知的第四座风泉，以及在游戏中无时无刻都能感受到的，这个异世界中的一切一切。

[h1] 奇幻的异世界[/h1]

　　这个游戏有独特的世界观。举几个我觉得有趣的例子来说明：

　　罪恶机器：这是艾斯波西亚特有的一种判别罪行的机器，犯了罪的人可以走到罪恶机器跟前，向它坦白罪行。听完罪行后机器会给出惩罚判定，比如说，打自己一嘴巴之类的。有意思的是，如果你坚持自己无罪的话，罪恶机器会送你一颗薄荷糖。但是坚持无罪的话就要忍受机器喋喋不休的“要认清自己的罪孽！”

格尔夫：皮肤具有强烈的腐蚀性，有非常强劲的咬合力，锋利的爪子还带毒。普通人只要碰一下它们就会死掉，如果两只格尔夫相恋的话……那它们离死也不远了。就是看起来这么无敌的格尔夫，居然会因为只要碰到地面地面就会被腐蚀塌陷使得它们无法行动而终生受困于石头上无法行动。这设定真的是很讽刺。

　　筋斗耗子：非常可爱的小耗子，外表有点像软绵绵的绵羊，作为宠物似乎在艾斯波西亚广受好评。

[h1] 有趣的角色们[/h1]

　　两个主角中，罗伯特看起来总是让人感觉刺激性不足，要介绍他只要用一句“带有傻气的有点自卑的少年”就足矣。因为有这样的一位主人公，也使得平日中和ＮＰＣ的交流显得智障无比。在询问某首歌的时候有这样一段弱智对话：

“很好听对吧？我亲爱的妈妈以前经常唱给我听。”
”你是从哪学会这首歌的呢？“
“从我妈妈那里。”
“那你妈妈是从哪里学会这首歌的呢？”
“从她妈妈那里。”
“我懂了，那她妈妈是从哪里学会这首歌的呢？”
“从风里听到了！哦，够了！”

　　女主角劳拉看起来就完全不一样。她是身负多个罪名的、通缉令贴满大街小巷的通缉犯，犯的罪大到偷东西小到在公共场所嚼口香糖什么都有，而游戏一开头指示鸽子去偷项链的也正是她。不过可千万别惹她！她和格芬丽娜之间的骂战让我充分感受到了女人之间的战争到底有多可怕。虽然她脾气火爆，却也有俏皮可爱的一面。在要去救罗伯特的时候，她还生怕别人误会似的补上一句“但这并不代表我喜欢他！我只是不讨厌他而已。大概吧。”很可爱，对吧？

　　私心地补充一句：劳拉的声优声音非常非常的好听哦！


[h1] 音游要素[/h1]

　　是的，你没看错，这个解谜游戏，它居然还有音游模式！曲子是贯穿整部游戏的主题曲，非常好听。主要是４键的下落式模式，而且是带ｋｅｙ音的！因为这是罗伯特的“笛子鼻”，所以也做成了像笛子一样，一起按住不同的孔会发出一个特定的音调的音，而不是像普通音游一样发出了两个键的两个音，更让人有种仿佛真的在吹笛子的感觉。

※带ｋｅｙ音即为按一下按键就会发出特定的按键音，不同于那种一首歌从头到尾播放到底，按键不发出任何声音的模式，有ｋｅｙ音的话只要演奏不对就会变成乱七八糟的曲子，如同真正的演奏一样。

[h1] 不友善的解谜游戏[/h1]

　　如果写评测是按照推荐度来排的话，那等到这时才写到最重要的解谜部分就代表我对这个系统还是颇有微词的。是的，这个游戏的解谜设计实在是算不上友好。

　　最突出的一点，就在于无用的干扰项非常多。这体现在每个地图中都有很多“看起来似乎有用”然而事实上并没有一点卵用的物品。它们可以被选中，可以调查和操作（假），很好地蒙蔽了玩家的双眼。而且让我意见很大的是它们的数量非常非常多，光是游戏的第一个场景就有５个！

　　除此之外，合成系统也让我有点意见。有些物品合成后根本没用，但是它们就是能合成！不止如此，有些物品的合成次数还很多，最多可以合成４次，而且那些物品互相之间根本看不出关联性，大概要合成到第三次时你才能开始察觉到自己究竟在合成什么，在关联性非常薄弱的情况下，玩家被迫的要使用穷举法来一个一个试，这似乎正合制作组的意，因为这个游戏，它甚至是鼓励使用穷举法的！有一个成就必须要在不看某两个提示的情况下瞎试３０～５０次成功才能解锁，这真是让我说什么才好……

[h1] 友善的提示[/h1]

　　这个游戏我最喜欢的就是这个部分——游戏自带的提示！它不像攻略那样直接告诉你要怎么怎么做，而是会循循善诱，一点一点地提示、启发玩家自己去思考。通常一个行动它可能要花上７、８个提示来诱导你。这样就避免了玩家卡关后苦苦思考不得志，最终不得不违心地去看攻略的情况。它贴心地为卡关的玩家预留了一个宽阔的思考空间，一点一点地引导玩家自行走向真相的大门。这一点做得真是非常好。


[h1]总结[/h1]

　　总的来说，我还是非常推荐这个游戏的。虽然它的解谜系统很不友善，这种无用物品很多的情况出现在冒险ＲＰＧ中很正常，但是出现在点击解谜游戏中就太折磨人了，但是与此相对的，它也有很友善的提示系统。世界观很独特，到处都是新奇的事物。人物的特点鲜明，全语音也很有诚意。

　　值得一提的是，这个游戏的ＰＣ版并没有汉化版。这个游戏有登录安卓和ＩＯＳ，这两个平台都有扑家汉化组进行汉化，然而ＰＣ版却没有。

　　最后，感谢赠送这个游戏给我的＠Rapture，现在的人安利真是太拼了，一言不合就送游戏。

Voto 7/10

The Inner world è un'avventura grafica molto buona e la consiglio a chiunque piaccia il genere ma è anche un ottimo punto di partenza per chi voglia provare. 

Il protagonista è molto ingenuo ed è facile empatizzare per lui ed essere coinvolti dalla sua "favola". 

La parte migliore del gioco è l'umorismo sempre calzante. La storia è carina e anche se non c'è nessun colpo di scena è ben raccontata. 

La parte peggiore sono i bug: ho dovuto riavviare il gioco 3 volte e alla fine c'erano due musiche di sottofondo contemporaneamente: OUCH! E inoltre ci sono delle schermate di caricamento inspiegabilmente lunghe. 

Questo unito a delle animazioni non eccelse e qualche altro difetto minore mi fa valutare il gioco 7 invece di 8. Ma resta una gran bella avventura grafica che consiglio caldamente

+ Storia carina
+ Enigmi carini
+ Voci e musica ok
+ Ottimo sistema di suggerimenti integrato nel gioco 

- La grafica poteva essere migliore
- Lunghe schermate di caricamento
- Alcuni bug
- Non c'è la traduzione in italiano

21690412.review:
Решил написать кратко плюсы и минусы игры, которые я выделил во время прохождения:

Плюсы:  

+ Играть было действительно интересно.

+ Потрясающий визуальный стиль. Игра воспринимается как хороший мультфильм. Понравилось как нарисованы персонажи: просто, но что-то в них цепляет.  

 + Юмор. Играл полностью на английском языке(знания по нему у меня так себе), но в игре совсем не скучал. Наверное, хорошо проникся атмосферой. Второй забег устрою уже с русификатором. 
   Не было желания сразу забросить игру, как это у меня частенько бывает с играми на другом языке. Довольно хорошо получалось улавливать смысл диалогов, хоть и не мог переводить их дословно. Поэтому могу сказать, что диалоги в игре не очень сложные, простые для понимания.

+ Интересные персонажи. У каждого свой характер. Но тут немного спорный момент. Кому-то характеры персонажей могут показаться заезженными, знакомыми. Мне кажется, что тут присутствует некая шаблонность, знакомая нам по мультфильмам.

+ Озвучка. Очень понравился подбор голосов. 

+ Музыкальное сопровождение. Музыка на фоне не раздражала, а лишь дополняла происходящее на экране. Так что плюс. 

Минусы: 

- За 10 часов игры пришлось два или три раза отключать игру через alt+f4, так как игра зависала.

- Если играете без чтения прохождений, то придется пройти через очень много повторений, так как решения некоторых ситуаций совсем не очевидны (возможно, тут сказалось моё "знание" оригинального языка). В игре есть встроенная система подсказок, так что, при желании, можно пройти игру особо не напрягаясь.

- Иногда было непонятно, когда надо собрать/разобрать предмет.

- Довольно простой сюжет. Разочарования не вызывает, но и до вау-эффекта ему далеко. Без изысков. Хорошая история.

- Вряд ли будет продолжение.

I really liked the artstyle of this game, and the idea behind the world (very creative) - but, unfortunately, this is where the praise ends.

Whoever was responsible for the initial game idea and story outline must have died or left the team right after supplying it, because (s)he sure didn't participate in the puzzle design, dialog or further story writing. The main character is an absolute dimwit making it impossible to connect with him. The dialog is badly written which is making the voice acting cringe-worthy to listen to.

The puzzles are utterly ridiculous - they are super random, often defy (even adventure-)logic and some cannot even be solved by doing the right thing on the "wrong" screen (yes, I'm talking about you, theatre stage conroy mod); or they require you to have completed only loosely connected dialog trees with random NPCs before working. Ontop of this, items can sometimes be combined in the wrong way, which is making things unnecessarily confusing.

Overall, this game was not a pleasant experience. I completed only the first chapter (which took me a good two hours), had everyone flee my twitch stream in panic and would rather shoot myself in the foot than continue playing.

Someone please hire Studio Fizbin's artist and pair him up with people who actually care about their work.

21431064.review:
Ладный классический квест, догоняющий своих крупнобюджетных собратьев. Пара дополнительных локаций, чуть больше продолжительность - и он не уступал бы им ни в чем. Новая необычная вселенная и любопытные персонажи успешно расцвечивают знакомую историю спасения мира. Все игровые составляющие для жанра на вполне высоком уровне. Иннер ворлд больше квест про взаимодействие предметов, а не решение автономных паззлов. Логика в первом присутствует, хотя периодически может выкинуть фокус в стиле Депонии, где она в духе своего мира бывает крайне оригинальной. У Иннер ворлда вообще имеются схожие черты с Депонией, разве что градус геймплейного и сценарного безумия явно пониже, несмотря на то, что мир ИВ сам по себе не менее причудлив. Кстати, для предметного квеста, инвентарь в нем не набивается со временем тоннами предметов, все быстро идут в оборот и обновляются. Занятно, что случается необходимость разобрать уже собранную конструкцию и пустить запчасти на другое дело. 
Игровых персонажей двое, тихоня Роберт, чья наивность – смертельное оружие, и бойкая Лора. Изрядная доля юмора как раз-таки базируется на взаимоотношениях Роберта и открытого мира, в который он попадает из продолжительного принудительного затворничества. Вообще Роберт вышел довольно незаурядным персонажем, кто-то из рецензентов несправедливо счел его глупым, замечая только его наивность.
Визуально ИВ приятен, хороши анимации, которые подчас напоминают качественный мультфильм. Немаловажно, что ролики, повторяющиеся моменты и диалоги можно скипать. К слову, в отрицательных отзывах люди писали о затянутых диалогах, в которых повторяется одно и то же. Это действительно проблема, если упрямо кликать на темы диалогов до того, как они станут неактивными. Только никакой нужды в этом нет, достаточно прочитать, что от тебя хотят, один раз и не надрываться. Предположу, что так было сделано на случай, если забудешь, что требуется для прохождения. На этот же случай предусмотрены многоуровневые подсказки, начинающие с намеков. 
В итоге – игра стоит покупки и времени.

21160236.review:
A short adventure game with some charm and enough of a hook to keep you interested for a playthrough.  While it is polished enough to be worth your time, it hasn't enough charm or substance in the storytelling to keep you engrossed.

A first stab at the adventure genre by the developers, they've told a story of a little boy who is a member of an underground civilization plagued by a number of problems, first are all these wind gods turning people into stone and the second being the absence of wind.  The world is foreign and interesting enough with its own history, culture, and physics that keep you guessing and interested in what is happening and what led up to the present sequence of events.  The story is, boy gets caught up in problem, meets anarchist girl, ends up in revolution, discovers past, bad stuff happens, uses past to save the world, live happily ever after.  The story is adventure game fodder and is not done exceptional enough to make it seem new or like something I haven't played already.

The dialogue was translated from German and it was done well enough save for some patchy words which made it into the localization, misnamed objects, odd sentences and the like.  As far as that goes, there is a LOT of dialogue.  Your mileage may vary if you consider this a good or bad thing.  It provides a lot of exposition, character development, and world building.  It also starts falling into the land of monotonous walls of text.  If you are having any issues with a dialogue puzzle, you can expect to see the same lines repeated several times.

The art is done to give the game its own style.  It's cartoony, imaginative, and contributes to the development of the story and world.  The only issue I had with it was it had so much drab and brown, but that's for my own tastes.

The puzzles, dialogue and inventory, are done well and help the pacing, which is all I can ask of puzzles in an adventure game.  They are well-made and don't require the use of LOL logic to figure out.  Their difficulty improves gradually over the game and helps immersion and pacing.  If you have problems, the game has an interactive hint book which can help push you in the right direction.  There's nothing really bad I can say about them other than the repetition you may face if you have issues with a dialogue puzzle.

In all, the game is ok and I had no real problems with it.  The only problem is, it exists in a genre swamped with better games and other games no better than this one.  If you are an adventure game fan, you can play this for something new.  Otherwise, look for something else.

If you enjoyed The Whispered World, The Night of The Rabbit, Deponia Series, Monkey Island Series, Satinav/Memoria, etc. than you should definately pick this up. Also the soundtrack is totally worth it!

20721784.review: This is fairly traditional point and click game, i.e. you have to collect everything not nailed down and rub it against everything else till the story progresses. This kind of gameplay can get frustrating when you cannot work out the insane combinations of items required to solve the puzzle but this game gets round this by a very nice hints system. Unlike the hints systems in some of the Telltale games which gives you hints that only make sense if you know the solution, this hint system gives you loads of little hints and if you keep clicking it eventually just tells you what to do. This is a really nice system as you just use it till you get the bit of information you need to make all the clues click together into place without having to go away and look up a full walkthrough. Aside from that is has a cool world with likeable characters and a good story which is really what you are looking for in a point and click game.

This is a point and click adventure filled with cutscenes and fantastic voice acting. The story and the puzzles were fun. There were some really big performance issues with this game however. 
1. The loading times between each area was longer than one would expect (10+ seconds maybe)? 
2. Some delay between clicking and the text popping up / sound playing (probably a loading issue)
3. Black screens... this happened to me at least 3 times. Going from one 'area' to another caused a complete blackout - only a restart bypassed it. This may have had to do with cutscenes not playing properly. I'm not sure why.

In terms of size, this game felt really small... as each act only had about 3-4 areas were you could explore. Additionally, the number of characters you could interact with were a small handful as well. This meant that most of the dialog in each act were from only one or two characters. I felt having so few characters was a terrible decision as it meant characters would literally drone on and on monotonously. 

Unfortunately for all of this. This is only a 6.5/10 for me. The story was fun, puzzles were fun, but the performance issues  and the design choice of having few areas + few characters really made the game slow.

20557413.review:
A really interesting game! This one might be a little long, sorry guys!

I tend to be very on or off with point and clicks, It doesn't happen very often that i get into a game of this genre, don't get bored half way through, and actually manage to get to the end of it.

The tendency with this genre for me is that if they don't flow well enough, if i get stuck on obscure item combinations (which happens a lot with point and clicks) or if it's just not interesting enough, i'll give up and not bother going back to it. This is one point and click game however that i am happy to say that not only could i actually bare to get through it, but it's actually a really good game. It's been the best point and click game i have played since the Deponia series, which i adored.

In ways, this game reminded me a little of that series. I guess in just style and art. I was actually somewhat convinced whilst playing that it might be by Daedalic Entertainment, but alas it's not!

Admittedly when i first started playing this, i thought it was quite slow (maybe i was just in a particularly impatient mood that day?). The dialog seemed like it was paced too slowly and i was generally dreading the trek ahead to completing this game. Although I'm glad to say i changed my mind very quickly with that one.

The story is very inventive and i found it quite interesting. The game was fun to play through and the ending was definitely not disappointing. I think i can safely say that it's not the plot twist of the century, but it's not entirely predictable either. Either way it was great to see things unfold and i loved the creativity and humor involved.

In terms of characters, I love them. There are some very lovable characters in this game. Including our main star Robert. A well mannered, polite, silly and somewhat naive little Asposian. 

The graphics are nice. It's very soft, light and nice on the eyes. A light-hearted, hand-drawn and cartoon-like style. With that said, i did have a few problems with crashing/freezing. Sometimes the loading screen between chapters just wouldn't load. It was usually fine because the game tends to autosave before the "end of chapter" cutscene. So you don't really lose anything, but it's still a minor annoyance having to reboot the game. 
I found that if you tended to not move or click anything whilst the cutscene was playing or it was trying to load, it'd usually load fine. If you pressed buttons and clicked your mouse, that's when it tended to have a hard time and freeze.

That being the only negative thing out of the way, back to the positive stuff!
The help system in this is quite good. I usually try not to use hints whenever i can, but being stuck on something for a long while gets a bit frustrating. I was quite impressed with the hint system, I wanted to see how many hints it would give you and how obvious they'd be. It gives you a few little nudges in the right direction before just spelling it out to you. Plus, you still don't get it? It'll spell it out to you even more blatantly. Literally to the point of "Go pick this thing up over there, and use it on this".

Lastly, achievements!
This one is pretty easy to complete 100% and i think my method for doing so was a decent way of doing it. 
I basically started a game file (it allows you up to 3), I played through a chapter, then went back to the main menu and started a second game for missed achievements throughout each chapter. Every time i would complete a chapter in my main save, i'd go back to the secondary save to complete it again whilst getting any missed achievements. 
The chapters aren't too long and once you know what you are doing going back and getting the missables in a second game file isn't as tedious as it sounds. 
There is one lonesome guide for this game that details "missable achievements" you can either read the names/descriptions and try to figure yourself how to get them, or you could just use the guide to know what to do. (In my opinion it's fairly easy to figure out how to get them just from reading the title or description)
Also, there are a few achievements that having two saves actually makes it easier. For example, there is one achievement for not using the guide at all and one for using the guide frequently. So either way really, you'd have to play it twice. 

All in all i really loved this game and i'm glad i decided to have a go with it. If you're a fan of the genre i would definitely recommend it to you.

19980832.review:
7/10 Punkte

[h1]Nicht Daedelic? Nee, aber fast so gut![/h1]


"Ein deutsches Point&Click-Adventure? Ganz klar, muss von Daedelic sein!" - so oder so ähnlich ist wohl der erste Eindruck eines jeden Genreliebhabers, wenn er von "The Inner World" hört. Und wenn die zuständigen Entwickler Studio Fizbin ihr Logo nicht in den Ladebildschirm beim starten des Spiels gesetzt hätten, man würde auch nach der sechs bis acht Stunden langen Rätselei davon ausgehen, dass Daedelic Entertainment hinter dem Titel stecken würde. Und das in vollkommen positiven Sinne.

Ob nun die stimmungsvolle Welt, die atmosphärischen Schauplätze, die tolle Musik, die meist gut designten (und manchmal auch kreativen) Rätsel, oder die liebenswürdigen und durchgeknallten Charaktere und deren Humor - vieles in "The Inner World" ist auf hohem Niveau umgesetzt und begeistert. Auch wenn es technisch teilweise nicht ganz gepolished wirkt (relativ wenig Schauplätze, lange Ladezeiten, teilweise unnötige Umwege für manche Rätsel, hakelige Animationen, die aber nur selten vorkommen, da viel auch in tollen Videosequenzen erzählt wird, nicht ganz perfekte Betonung, vor allem bei Lauras Sprechrolle), stören diese Kritikpunkte das tolle Spielgefühl nicht.

Wohl aber die Bugs - das Spiel hat durchaus noch einige Fehler. Bei mir waren diese durch ein Neuladen des Spielstandes oder einen Neustart des Spiels zu beheben, es soll aber auch A-Bugs geben, die man nur mit einem von den Entwicklern zugesendeten Speicherstand umgehen kann. Das ist schade und frustrierend, auch wenn das Bemühen der Entwickler um Aushilfe löblich ist und das ganze durch geringes Budget zu erklären ist. Es wäre schön gewesen, wenn man verschiedenen Speicherstände pro Durchlauf anlegen könnte, so wäre zum Einen die Gefahr von A-Bugs verringert, zum anderen aber auch die Achievement-Jagd erleichtert (und die lohnen sich wirklich! Selten habe ich so kreative und lustige Errungenschaften gesehen. Es lohnt sich auf jeden Fall, die Beschreibung dieser im Steam-Profil noch einmal nachzulesen :D).

Allgemein lässt sich feststellen, wieviel Mühe und Hingabe in das Spiel geflossen ist. Das macht es wirklich zu einem sehr schönen Erlebnis. Da stören nur die Rätsel in Kapitel 3 ein wenig - finden die Rätsel meist genau die richtige Balance zwischen "einfach nachvollziehbar" und "herausfordernde Knobelei", gibt es in diesem Kapitel einige Frustmomente. Da hilft dann aber die tolle Rätselhilfe aus. Genau so sollte eine solche Funktion aussehen - kleine Hinweise und Gedankenanstöße geben, ohne sofort die ganze Rätsellösung vorweg zu nehmen, auch wenn das, wenn gewünscht, möglich ist - ganz großes Kompliment!

"The Inner World" ist ein tolles Spiel - aber eben auch ein Erstlingswerk eines jungen, neuen deutschen Entwicklerstudios. Das merkt man dem Spiel an - wenig Screens, technisch etwas unausgereift und insgesamt relativ kurz. Über diese Probleme kann man jedoch problemlos hinwegsehen. "The Inner World 2" wurde neulich angekündigt, ich bin schon sehr gespannt!

A very nice and charming point & click game. Reminds me a bit of deponia in its dark yet humorous story, interesting setting, nice music, and weird characters.

Pros:
- The story is pretty good (although I wouldn't rate it as great...)
- The characters are alright... although somewhat idiotic and rather shallow.
- I personally really liked the music, it fits the game very well in my opinion.
- The game has a very unique (and really good!) hint system, which gives you a tiny piece of information every time you click (so it doesn't give you the entire answer unless you REALLY want it!)

Cons:
- There are a few bugs (and translation issues) in the game - some that caused me to re-load my save - but none that are game breaking, or actually more than a nuisance.
- The loading times can get annoying at times (especially when you need to move between areas a lot to figure out a particular puzzle).
- There are some puzzles which I wouldn't have figured out without the hint system, but not too many.

Overall it's a very nice game, about 4-6 hours long, and I would recommend it to those who like a casual point & click adventure game.

The Inner World est un point and click dans lequel on incarne Robert, un citoyen Asposian, tellement innocent que l'on ne peut que s'y attacher, et qui cherche un pendentif qui se révèlera est le début d’une plus grande aventure.

La difficulté de ce jeu est bien dosé à mes yeux, peux être trop simple pour certain, mais la difficulté n’est pas ici le but recherché. Les objectifs des tableaux sont clairs, bien que les actions pour leur réalisation ne soit pas évidentes au premier abord à cause de combinaison fantaisiste. Heureusement, dans le cas où le déclic ne se produit pas, il y a une aide très riche en indice.

Au sujet de l'histoire bien qu’elle soit linéaire, elle est le point fort du jeu. L’histoire est certes coute mais sympathique et mignonne avec une petite pointe d'humour. On se retrouve même un peu surpris par les péripéties à chaque fin des 5 chapitres.

La petite touche d'originalité de ce point and click est l’ajout du Game Play d’une flute à 4 trous et qui sera utile dans 2 situations où il faudra en jouer quelques notes en utilisant les touches 1-2-3-4, rien de bien compliqué, mais c'est à souligner. J’ai même été dessus que la flute ne soit pas plus utilisée.

Les graphismes du jeu me font pensé a certain dessin animé pour enfant et qui colle tous a fait avec le ton de l'histoire.
Un bon divertissement qui m'a pris personnellement 8 heures en jouant tranquillement, mais il doit être faisable en 5-6 heures.

18483384.review:
Deliziosa avventura grafica ad opera di uno studio tedesco, The Inner World è ambientato in un piccolo mondo cavo e ci vede nei panni di Robert, giovane apprendista dal curioso naso a flauto e figlio adottivo del severo abate Conroy che governa la città. Così, per recuperare un ciondolo rubato da un piccione, Robert finisce nella parte bassa della città, dove si imbatte nella bella fuorilegge Laura (di cui si innamora subito), e nel suo peregrinare si rende conto che forse le cose non stanno come Conroy gliele ha sempre descritte… 

Impreziositi da una grafica adorabile con ottime animazioni, i personaggi sono il punto forte di TIW. Robert è molto ingenuo e un po' tonto, mentre Laura è più scaltra e cinica e svilupperà un rapporto molto particolare con lui. C'è molto di Monkey Island in tutto questo, e a volte sembrerà un po' di vedere le schermaglie tra Guybrush ed Elaine. Ma anche i personaggi di contorno non sono da meno, sono quasi tutti molto fuori di testa e sopra le righe.

Gli enigmi sono generalmente buoni, anche se ogni tanto prevale l'apparente nonsenso come nei titoli di Gilbert e che costringe al "proviamo tutto con tutto", ma per quanto strana una logica c'è più o meno sempre. È comunque presente un sistema di aiuti molto esaustivo, perciò è difficile rimanere bloccati. 

Eccellente anche il comparto audio, con un'enormità di dialoghi (a volte quasi eccessivi) doppiati interamente in inglese da voci azzeccatissime specialmente per i protagonisti, e musiche di sottofondo altrettanto belle.

La longevità è nella media, direi 6-7 ore, dipende quanto si rimane bloccati se non si vuole guardare gli aiuti. Il motore di gioco per qualche ragione non è stabilissimo e potrebbe crashare durante alcuni filmati, ma a parte questo non gli trovo particolari difetti seri. È un'AG molto carina con personaggi ben caratterizzati, e tanto basta per essere piacevole da giocare.

Ein wunderbares Adventure für Groß und Klein! (Nun ja, wegen bestimmter Anspielungen und expliziten Texten vielleicht eher was für Groß). Mit Witz, Herz und einer wunderbaren Story, hat mich The Inner World wirklich verzaubert.
Robert ist ein ganz einfacher Asposier, mit einer seltsamen Nase. Doch ganz gewöhnlch ist er nicht, denn er ist der einzige Novize des großen Conroy. Eines Tages wird Conroy ein wichtiges Amulett von einer diebischen Taube gestohlen. Ein Sprung in den Müllschacht und Robert stolpert in sein Abenteuer. Der naive, liebenswürdige Held verdient hierbei eine besondere Erwähnung. The Inner World schafft es eine eigentlich dunkle und steinige Höhlenwelt, lebendig und interessant zu gestalten, ihr wirklich Leben einzuhauchen. Der Grafikstil, die Animationen und die wirklich großartige deutsche Vertonung tun dann ihr übriges. Selten war ich von solch einem Gesamtpaket so begeistert. Die einzige Kritik, die ich noch äußern könnte, wären vereinzelte abstruse Rätsel. Es kam ein zwei mal vor, dass ich durch pures Raten und "Random ein paar Dinge aus Verzeweiflung kombinieren", auf die Lösung eines Rätsel gekommen bin. Allerdings macht es das ingame Tipp-System unmöglich, etwas nicht zu schaffen. Die Tipps sind wirklich sehr schön und in Stufen aufgebaut, so dass man sich nicht direkt die ganze Aufgabe spoilert.
Ich kann dieses Adventure wirklich jedem empfehlen, Anfängern im Genre, alten Hasen auf dem Gebiet oder Menschen, die einfach auf gut geschriebenen Witz und Handlung abfahren. Hier kann man eigentlich nichts falsch machen.

17812282.review:
A hilarious and adorable adventure game that I will remember fondly as one of my favorite point and click advetnures in some time. Phenomenal voice acting, cute characters, charming dialogue, good puzzles, and just an overall fun experience watching the characters try to save their people. 

We begin with Robert, an orphaned boy who is being raised by a man named Conroy. Conroy is the ruler of this little world of Asposia, and right away, as you can in all animated tales, we realize that Conroy isn't the nicest of fellows. In fact, he seems like a downright meanie. :P One day while Robert is playing his flute nose (yes, I said flute nose) for Conroy in his favorite 1 note tune, a pigeon that Robert has been playing with as one of his only friends comes in and steals Conroy's necklace and flies off. Robert, being the ever dutiful 'son' goes after it and finds himself down in the city of Asposia with all the peasants for the first time outside the walls of Conroy's castle. His adventure is ready to begin...

Robert soon meets residents of Asposia and quickly starts to realize that Conroy may not be the great hero that he was raised to believe he was. Most importantly he meets Laura. A wanted thief, general troublemaker, obvious anti-establishment hero, and the girl of Robert's dreams. Robert is incredibly naive, but falls in love with Laura at first site. She is more worldy and they play off one another fantastically as she teases him and he shows his innocence again and again as a kind and generous boy. Their conversations are great, and Robert is pretty funny no matter how innocent he is. 

I didn't find any issues with the game UI, or the puzzle mechanics. They are the standard hover over the bottom of the screen to pop up the item menu, with options to drag them to world objects, combine them, etc. Some of the puzzles are a bit strange and take some trial and error of jsut screwing aroudn finding what items interact with things, but overalll they aren't too illogical most of the time. The game has a few loading screens between areas that on my medium level PC took about 3 seconds to load wasn't a problem for me. 

I had no bugs in the game that I can recall. Certainly nothing that made me stop, although the save system is not one that is the type to be friendly for Achievement hunters. The game can be saved manually, or using auto-saves, BUT you don't have a choice about where you save other than picking a slot for your current game. So you have one save and if it auto-saves and you miss an Achievement you will have to start the game over. So...if 100% Achievements is your goal then you better take a look at some Achievements guides BEFORE starting. There are a few that are full game achievements and a couple of them contradict. One side is really easy and can be gotten with a quick restart early on, but the other requires the full game to be played a certain way so you want to make sure you understand these early on before finding out halfway through you will have to play all the way through again.  

Game is probalby anywhere from 6-10 hours long. My playtime is longer because I left the game on for 12 hours one day. :)

If you are a fan of point and click adventure games, love games such as the ones made by Daedelic, love cute and adorable characters with phenomenal voice acting, then The Inner World is a fantastic game for you. While this is an Indie studio, and this is their first major game, I consider this adventure game to be as good as any of the Daedelic games I have played. It definitely could be considered as comparable in quality to those. I highly recommend it to any adventure fan. I loved the characters and would love to see more from this studio. 

Bringing me to this...

NOTE: While looking at videos for The Inner World on Youtube I noticed this trailer from 2013 that suggested there might be an animated cartoon coming called 'The Inner World', but I ahve found no other news about it. I would have definitely watched, but it gives you a pretty good idea about the voice acting in the game as it is similar to this cartoon. If anyone knows anything else about this animated series I would be interested. :)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=STsqPrG8L7E

17215561.review:
Played through twice. Once to complete and once again to get the achievements I'd missed. Second playthrough took about an hour and a half with me skipping all dialogue and cutscenes, the rest of the time was spent going through puzzles and watching loading screens. Actually that made me notice a lot of the puzzles had a lot of wandering back and forth between locations but that's a minor criticism. Otherwise the short playtime is to be expected when you already know the solutions to all the puzzles, so it shows there is a decent amount of content there. I'd estimate 6 to 10 hours depending on how quick you are on the uptake.

First playthrough I completed with know guides or help from the hint system. I did scratch my head occasionally but it's not an exceptionally hard point and click adventure. The majority of the puzzles make logical sense and most the time you know what you want to do and the challenge is more in finding the right items to do it. If you are stuck it usually means you need to go back and talk to someone now you know more or you just missed and item in another area. Holding down the left mouse button shows all the hot spots for objects you can interact with on the screen so thankfully pixel hunting is not a barrier like the old days of P&C. If you do get stuck there's an in game help system that tells you what your goals are and can get successively more detailed hints on what to do next from, so you still wont need a guide to help you complete it.

The art style is styalised as you can see from the screenshots above. Appeal comes down to personal opinion. The quality of the art assets is adequate for what they are trying to convey. I didn't find myself not knowing what something was when I looked at it.

Sound wise the voice acting is decent enough, soundFX are adequate to indicate what they are and the music sets the mood without been noteworthy enough to get in the way of your attention. In otherwords it all serves it's purpose.

The story is well written and very original. There's a decent amount of lore to give depth to this unique universe and it is delivered with good pacing to keep the mysteries unfolding all the way to the end. Characters are well designed, you like and contempt them as appropriate and as such feel satisfied when they get what they deserve (good or bad). Dialogue is amusing whenever it's not supposed moving. I would say it's laugh out loud funny but I went through most the game with a bemused smile. 

The emotional drama isn't exactly gripping, in spite of it's content it doesn't feel super dark and gripping or a tear jerker like some other games in the genre (try some deadalic titles like chains of satinav of whispered world for that). It's interesting, it walks a tight right where you do feel sympathy for the characters without been devastated by the tragedy constantly befalling them. In other worlds it's pretty light hearted if still a little grim at times. 

Loading times aside (they are short but still noticeable enough to annoy you when you realise you have to backtrack because you forgot something) my biggest criticism would have to be stability. Very occasionally the cut scene animations didn't play correctly when completing a puzzle (no impact on gameplay you just miss out on the visual) and the game would periodically crash, I'd say you can expect it to do so 3-5 times between the begging of the game and completion. Thankfully the game autosaves after literally everything you do so you never lose any progress. Another example of how it's not super polish but enough work was put in to make sure things are good enough to preform to resonable expectations.  

In summary this is a solid addition to the genre and at the end of the day the game left me hoping for a sequel to be released in the future, which in my book is as solid a recommendation as any.

16907764.review:
[h1]Short version: 86%[/h1]
The Inner World is a classic point-and-click adventure game about a strange, alien planet, a meek protagonist who ends up on a world-wide conspiracy, and some old-school hardcore problem solving, all wrapped within a cosy atmosphere.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
The Inner World is so far the largest game released by German independent developer Studio Fizbin. It is the kind of point ‘n’ click adventure that doesn’t shy away from ludicrous puzzles, but gives you a really unique storytelling experience in return.

It takes place inside a world where natural laws differ greatly from ours. An alien planet which seems quite “human” in some respects, but different enough to leave the door open for creativity, imagination, and overall good writing.
You play a very naïve, shy hero, whose day starts off with a seemingly small accident, but he soon finds himself in a revolution against an oppressing religious dictator for the control of the most precious commodity: air. Don’t expect the usual story development though, because the plot has a few clever tricks along the way.
The cast is quite small, but even the supporting members are enjoyably memorable. The voice actors do a decent job, but nothing spectacular.

As an adventure game, it is moderately difficult. The item usage follows a really weird and twisted logic, but it is not completely impossible. (Plus it has a step-by-step hint system as backup.) Thanks to this, the play time can easily be pushed over 6-7 hours, which is fairly decent for this price category.

16302803.review:
《The Inner World》是德国的一个小工作室Studio Fizbin  2013年的点点点作品，流程大约6小时。虽然本作没有什么特别令人惊艳的地方，但是完成度很高，整体没有什么短板，还有一些贴心的小设计，因此个人觉得是个7.5分的中等作品。

画面：7.5/10。本作的画面是PS上色版儿童画风格，有些玩家可能会不习惯。虽然画风貌似粗糙，但细看会发现是美工有意为之，实际还是非常精细的。整体画风也走的童话范，魔幻的感觉把握的很不错；但唯一的小问题是游戏场景色调中性色偏多，人设又不甚美型，玩着可能会感觉单调。

音乐和配音：8/10。本作的主旋律和剧情紧密相关，实际上表现也很不错，悠扬的陶笛曲和魔幻童话相得益彰，其它的场景配乐也很有水平。配音方面，本作由于是德国工作室作品，因此也有德语和英语两种配音；本人用英语打的，感觉配音质量不错……话说感觉主角小哥声线略像《The Whispered World》主角，难道真的是同一cv么？

剧情：7/10。个人打过的德系点点点游戏中，剧情的最大特点就是设定完整逻辑清晰，虽然故事本身有些老套，人物塑造也是中规中矩；但是故事和世界观很完整，也没什么逻辑槽点和设定坑，玩起来比较舒服。本作的剧情就是标准德系点点点的剧情，各种欧美系狗血老梗（比如[spoiler] 杀父仇人是养父啥的	[/spoiler]）也是一应俱全，最后也是喜闻乐见的HE（[spoiler]如果不介意男主最后还是父母双亡的话	[/spoiler]）；但是世界观设定的很有意思，和解谜的结合也不错，一些争议点也被很机智的回避掉了，总的来说还不错。

解谜和系统：7.5/10。本作自带提示系统，卡关党请自行查看。总的来说，本作的谜题并不难，提示也给的很到位，非常良心。而且尽管游戏流程只有5章6小时，但是谜题种类并不单调（未传之书你听见了没！黑的就是你！）；第二章可以操作女主，而第三章之后增加了男主鼻子奏乐的特殊功能，这两点笔者觉得相当不错。不过和其他德系点点点一样，本作也有个把鬼畜谜题靠试错的问题……你们这群德国死宅都是一个师傅教的？

系统上，各种操作教学好评。本作也是自带空格显示热点的业界良心功能，但是跳过场动画居然也是空格键有点坑(-__-)b 游戏还附带一个吹奏主题曲的小音游，只玩到20000+的手残党表示不明觉厉。至于别的吧……游戏刚上Steam的时候有一些成就bug，不过现在应该是修复了；有时候会有点不到的现象，不过并不严重。

总的来说，《The Inner World》算是近两年点点点作品里比较不错的，难度也相当亲民，适合各位尝试一下；作为有卡有成就的游戏，本作有75 OFF和进包过，推荐大家尝试。

P.S.攻略请参见下面这篇指南：
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=458048995
