15677765.review:
This is a Spolier Free review.

The Inner world takes place in Asposia, an inverted world of kind with the air and light being brought in by Wind Fountain and Fosfos's respectfully. In this new world we meet Robert, the adopted son of the Wind Monk to the last remaining Wind Fountain. In this world, the Basylians, wind gods, are angry with the people of Asposia and have begun to rampage and turn people into stone. Conroy, the last active wind monk, is the pope like figure in control over all of Asposia trying to save the people of this world by pleasing the Basylians to not turn the citezens into stone.  The story starts off by Robert polishing Conroy's most precious medallion, a stray pidgeon appears and Robert befriends the pidgeon but shoo's the pidgeon away as Conroy finishes his speach. Robert fearful of Conroy hands him his medallion only for the medallion to get stolen by the pidgeon. Robert wanting to please Conroy chases after the pidgeon. This is where we meet Laura, the owner of the pidgeon and wanted by the state for a multitude of crime. Laura catches Robert trying to steal the pidgeon, which belongs to her, and she grabs the pidgeon, whos name is now known as Peck, and runs off. Thus beginning the story of The Inner World.

Throughout the rest of the game you will meet interesting new characters each with thier own set of witty and humorous dialoges as well as an immensive world with many secrets to behold. Robert, being sheltered all his life enters this world much like the player giving a shared viewpoint through Robert. Robert, a very shy and honest character, has a magnetic personality that I found myself easily attaching myself to. His interactions with the world around him create humor at every corner. 

The humor in this game goes beyond character to character interactions, the game does not take itself seriously. In a later part of the game there is a cooking book called "Cooking for Posers by Gor Dun Ramsee", when I found this book I nearly fell to the floor laughing due to the call back to reality the game pulled on me. The world is filled with hints and nods to pop culture and the game itself is highly meta in its own rights.

While the story itself is nothing necessarily 'original' in story arc and plot points, the story is creative enough to work. The pacing of the story starts off very slow, but it gradually speeds up over time with some portions being slower than they should be. But the explosion of the storyline fits into the story arc of the game. Though the pacing fluxuated at certain points I was still enjoying the game due to the great story and the world of Asposia making me want more. The end of the story left me wanting more of this fantasy world that I fell in love with and I hope that in the future there could be a sequal or a storyline expansion to quench my thirst for more Asposia.

To add onto this amazing and humorous storyline and characters, the world itself is a beauty to look at. The animations are well crafted, though I did have some issues but that was only due to hardware problems, and it ties all of the story telling elements in to create an amazing fanasty world. 

I highly enjoyed playing through this entire game and I would play through it again to find the parts of the side story that I missed in my first playthrough. My only complaint is the games issues with AMD GPU's but that can be fixed by installing Adobe AIR. All in all this game is a very well rounded with an incredible story with meta humor splurged throughout the extraordinary world that is Asposia.

15462986.review:
The inner world.
A game that has reminded me of one of my favourite gaming genres of all time. The point and click.
It is hard to find a game nowadays with quite as much charm as the PaC genre did. Characters were often very quirky and memorable, puzzles were often (OFTEN) quite logical and made you think about how your character would think around in the world. The enviroments were stunning and mystifing, and the music was very atmospheric.

The inner world, is no exception.
The hand drawn animations, may turn some people off, as it isnt utulising the hardware, and making the best possible visuals, but the art style is something that i have not seen before, and it fits the world around it like a glove. 

The puzzles, while did have some symptoms of adventure game logic, still managed to appear solvable by anyone because everything you need is in the area. Only pixel hunt that i managed to find is an object, which is shown falling during a cutscene. If you still have trouble with a puzzle, the game offers a great hint system, which can either A: give you slight hints, to point you in the direction of what you are supposed to do, or after a fair number of these, B: Flat out give you the answer. 

The characters in the world are very quirky, silly, and each have their own unique traits that make themselves memorable. You will find yourself getting the achievement "Blabbermouth" (talk to each NPC at least once) fairly easily. The characters, whilst not having a sweeping backstory which tells a vast ammount of detail to give the characters intresting stories, still manages to achieve this in the designs, and the dialoge. (Best example would be the barmaid, who can be seen in the second screenshot, is against the gods of the game, and sins often.) 

The music is where the game becomes a bit weaker for me. Most of the tracks are fitting and add a lot to the atmosphere. However, there is nothing here that i would probably listen to outside of the game. However, the music is very charming and creative, like the rest of the game.

The story is also, a bit weaker than what i would have hoped. However, again it fits the world, the art style, and the gameplay well. For this i cant condemm it much further than i wish it were deeper behind the motives behind the main antagonist, and wish that i could learn a bit more about the world through hidden objects in the enviroments.

Also, this game is hilarious at points. The game allowes you to do things out of order, and not have the right answer straight away. For example, in most PaC, there is a solution, you need item X. To get item X, you combine X and Y, and use it on Z. In the Inner world, you combine X and Y, use it on story progresson before using it on Z, and you get a humerous clip showing what would happen. This is what most of the achievements in the game are for. The characters often have funny things to say, and the reactions that some characters have made me burst out laughing. "please, stop crying..." 
"I CAN CRY WHENEVER I WANT! ):<"

Ah, PaCs. Wish there were more of these. The inner world, reminded me of how good they are. If you have never played a PaC before, i implore you to pick this up. Don't try and play some of the old PaCs before this. They are still great, in every sence of the word, and some are better than this, but a modern gamer will be very confuzed, as there is a massive mind shift between traditional games today, and that of the past 2 decades. The inner world, did not have that problem. 

Overall, im not sure whether or not to give this game a score. If i compare it to the PaCs of yesteryear, it would not be a fair score, if i dont, im not being fair in judging it as a PaC. So, instead, im just going to say, buy the game. Its fairly cheap, and it will be a fun playthrough for you.


Also, i just wrote a wall of text. Sorry review page.

15172145.review:
The Inner World es un juego con un encanto inocente con ciertas referencias adultas; un point and clic sencillo, con una historia bonita y con una mezcla variada de puzzles.

El protagonista es un aposiano de 15 años que vive aislado en el palacio del viento, bajo la atenta supervisión del monje gobernador de la ciudad. Un día, una paloma fugitiva entra por su ventana, se traga el amuleto preferido del religioso y huye, obligando a Robert a bajar a los suburbios en su busca con la obligación moral de devolver el preciado colgante a su legítimo dueño.

PROS:
-Es una aventura gráfica entretenida, ideal para pasar el rato tranquilamente
-La música y los diseños son agradables, con unos personajes bien dibujados y caracterizados
-Alguna que otra vez sonsaca una risa, pero la mayoría del tiempo provoca ternura a causa de la personalidad inocente del protagonista principal
-Si en alguna ocasión te quedas atascado, se puede consultar el icono de pistas

CONTRAS:
-Algunos puzzles son bastante absurdos

"¿Me gustará este juego?"
 Si te gustan las aventuras gráficas, te hacen gracia los chistes sencillos e inocentes, y buscas un juego con buena estética y de historia bonita, hya muchas probabilidades de que The Inner World te guste. Si no te gusta lo de arriba mencionado, y odias controlar a protagonistas inocentones preguntones, directamente pasa de este juego, porque seguramente te va a aburrir.

7/10

15052245.review:
Wow... I don't know what to say... I made it to chapter 2 and then had to Alt+F4 it to end this misery. 

I bought this game because people said it would be funny and cleverly written and just an all over nice Adventure Game. Now, after forcing myself through about 2 hours of this game, I sit here and can't believe I wasted a money on something that is rated positive. 

I don't even know where to start. 

Let's begin with the positives

+ Nice graphics with a vector style look
+ Good voice actors were used in the making of this thing. The game sounds quite great. 

That's it. I can not say anything else positive. It may find a few moments as the game continues, but I can not see myself sitting there getting more and more annoyed.

Now, what are my issues with this:

- First and foremost the Game is still buggy. It came out in September 2013 and it still has problems. The first time I played it, I was stuck the same moment I entered the game. So I had to uninstall and re-install the game to get it to work. Once I got to chapter two, the game was stuck in loading screen and I had to restart it again. 

- Funny? People keep saying the game is funny. How is this game funny? I can't decide what's worse. The flat jokes or the incredible boring dialogues as well as sexist jokes along the way which are probably funny if you are 12 years old. Pseudo-funny sidecharacters make it even more unbearable. 

- The dialogues are not only not funny but also unnecessarily long and unimportant as well as non informative. 

- The main character is so annoyingly stupid that it makes me want to beat him. 

- Granted I did not see many puzzles and the ones I saw were okay. I guess some of them can be quite tricky, but it's not all too bad if you are used to adventure and puzzle games. 

- Random non-fitting noises. I don't know how it is in the rest of the game, but in the first chapter I was already bugged out by asking myself... WHY is there a continous "page turning" sound in the middle of the street where nobody reads a book or does something with books and WYH is there a register checkout sound near the jail?! 

- The story seems to be incredible weak. It has no tension, nothing exciting and even when it is supposed to have a adventorous turn, it ends in a boring loading screen which is so annoyingly long, that I ended up watching a video while waiting. The script of this Game is just as boring as the jokes...

I watched one of the most popular German Streamers play this game and even then I could not find the humor in it. Where he was laughing, I was continously facepalming myself and forwarding because even watching it was unbearable. 

I think if you are around an age class (real age or mental age) of 8-15 you might find this game funny.

15043916.review: I absolutely adored this game. The story and puzzles kept me engaged the whole way through, the humor was generally amusing, and the graphics are lovely. The game manages to convey a setting both grim and whimsical at the same time. The main character, Robert, is very endearing and a breath of fresh air in a genre seemingly dominated by sarcastic, cynical protagonists. He just makes you want to hug him. The puzzles generally felt logical but not overly straightforward, making you think outside the box. Goofy scenarios and imaginative settings are both positives, as well. I was very satisfied with every aspect of this game and especially impressed that it's the developer's first effort.

15043482.review:
I fell in love with this game as soon as I laid my eyes on the intro cutscene: so cute, so lovely, and so funny. Unfortunately my heart was broken not too long after.

The good: main character is lovable and a great vehicle for humor; great artwork; original, quirky setting; adorable critters with criminally too little screentime, like Peck, and the Gorfs have a welcome Adams-esque touch; the voicework solid and the music very nice, although the wind theme is oddly reminiscent of Oldboy's waltz (not complaining); the built-in hint system is extensive (luckily!).

The bad: I'd be hard pressed to name another recent adventure game so badly affected by moon logic: the gameplay hardly ever takes off, probably an attempt to squeeze length out of the assets. It's a mobile port, mostly workable, but leaving a room/location brings up a loading screen which is unbelievably slow, like the transitions in the UI. The story is functional at best, giving most characters some sort of motive, but is ultimately weak. Playing as Laura, in Chapter 2, she's just so whingy! The animations are far from smooth and the cutscenes often are lacking in detail. The translation, by virtue of being generally of good quality, makes the dozen or so non sequiturs stand out.

Recommended? tough call. On one side, it would have maybe worked better as a short animated film, for (too) much of my playing time I just wished I had watched a Let's Play instead. That's how miserable the puzzles made me.

OTOH these folks clearly have talent, and I'd like them to make more games.

15026338.review:
This game is totally great. If you've enjoyed Machinarium and The Dream Machine, you will definetely like this one! While it's slightly easier than both of them, I've still found myself stuck couple of times and going to their help system, which is great at giving hints without uncovering everything at once. The art is great, the sound is great and probably it's the most relaxing point and click I've ever played. Even comparing to Botanicula.

What could be possibly improved: 
1) Although I think that highlighting interactive spots makes game much less challenging and should be presented as an option of "easy" mode. Same goes for detailed hints, which are absolutely great, but knowing you have them makes you use them :)
2) Animations of combining things are almost useless, and probably should be presented as an option in settings.
3) What upset me the most after I completed the game - there's absolutely no way to start a separate chapter, so if you want to get all of the achievements you'll need to do it in the first run or play it again from the beginning just making to the points where you know you'll get achievements (they are rather obvious when you complete the game).

And while I liked this game a lot, I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price, though I can understand how much effort had been put in making it. If you absolutely want point-n-click for 10 bucks, I would recommend "The Dream Machine" instead. And still "Yes, I totally recommend this game".

The only "downside" are some of the puzzles rely on familiarity of how wind instruments work. They were cool and interesting, but I felt like a total idiot when playing through them and had quite a bit of trouble with them. I still sincerely recommend this game, though!

My favourite adventure game of the past few years, and I've played a lot of them.

Everything is great. An interesting and easy to follow story with some very humorous parts. Graphics and music/sound are excellent. Voice acting is good to excellent, the voice of the main character is excellent and his love interest is very good. Some characters like the various guards are obviously voiced by the same person, but this makes no difference. 

Puzzles are almost always very good. Usually the solution to a puzzle makes sense, only in a few cases are the puzzles not completely logical and even the few slightly illogical puzzles are not to hard to guess. I didn't have to use a walkthrough at all. The game takes about 8 to 10 hours to complete.

I didn't encounter any bugs in the game.

I hope they do a sequel or another adventure with the same development team.

Puzzles are not incredibly hard, and the hint system provides you with enough info if, for example, you're actually missing an object (oh, pixel hunting :) ). The story is good, the characters are hilarious with great voice-acting, and Robert... well, he's just a sweet little boy who goes on an adventure! I'm hoping for a sequel actually, only cause I loved the main character so very much! 

Plus, you can sing with your nose!

P.S. Part 2 is out now!

However, these puzzles were never solved with out of this world solutions, like a toothpaste and a comb made a lockpick. However, in an almost first puzzle [spoiler], the game would take the idea of drowning/flushing a worm out of its hole, and decide to make you use alcohol, and as such the worm is out because it is drunk. [/spoiler] The story was pretty predictable from the beginning, but was funny throughout. There are some mature/suggestive themes laced in a pretty tame and overall child friendly game.
I should point out two issues I had though. One was that the game about 3-4 times would get stuck while loading after a cutscene. In these cases I had to restart the game, but the pretty constant autosaving made this less of an issue. The other issue is deals with a hint system. 13990354.review:
The Inner World ist ein Point & Click Adventure, mit einem ganz besonderem Charm.
Als Robert, Novize und Ziehsohn des Windmönches Conroy werden wir ziemlich plötzlich in die, uns bisher unbekannte Außenwelt los gelassen und treffen dort llerlei skurille, lustige und verblüffende Charaktere. Diese führen uns sehr lebhaft und glaubwürdig in die Geschichte des Reiches Asposien ein.
Unsere Aufgabe besteht anfangs darin das Amulett zurückzuholen, dass von der Taube Hack geklaut worden ist. Was sich als einfache Aufgabe gibt, entwickelt sich im Laufe der Geschichte zu einem sehr witzigem, aber manchmal auch traurigem Abenteuer, in dem es erstaunlich viel um Wind geht. Doch spoilern werde ich an dieser Stelle nicht, denn die Story enthält einige überraschende Wendungen und mitreißende Erzählungen.
Die gaze Geschichte, das "Wie, warum weshalb" ist sehr stimmig und atmosphärisch gestaltet. Der grafikstil mag alt wirken, doch dies stört in diesem Spiel kein bisschen. Denn der naive Zeichenstil passt sehr gut zu der sehr naiven Einstellung vieler Charaktere, wie beispielsweise des protagonisten Robert.
Der Soundtrack ist schlicht, aber untermalt das ganze auch noch gut. Die Synchronisation ist fast ausnahmslos gelungen, lediglich den Windmönch zu Beginn hätte man etwas besser vertonen können.
Alles in allem ist The Inner World ein sehr süßes Spiel mit rund 6 Stunden Spieldauer, je nachdem wie schnell man ist. Die Steam-Errungenschaften kann man nicht in einem Gang schaffen, dafür muss man das Spiel zwei mal durchnehmen. Die Erfolge an sich sind auch nicht schnell gemacht, denn man mus sgezielt Dinge "Ffalsch machen", um die Erfolge zu bekommen. Viel rumprobieren und mit jedem doppelt und dreifach reden und mit Gegenständen sehr viel interagieren lohnt sich also, wenn man die Erfolge haben will.
Eine Kaufempfehlung für The Inner World wird vorbehaltlos ausgesprochen!

13231432.review:
Только что прошел эту прекрасную игру. Жаль, что стим не внес в статистику игру в автономе:(

Итак, как вы уже заметили, я написал: "прекрасную игру". И это действительно так.
Почему же я вынес подобный вердикт?

Давайте разберемся:
* Приятная рисовка. Игра имеет мультяшную графику, будто смотришь рисованный мультик (не то, что нынешнее компьютерное дерьмо).

* Отличная проработка диалогов. Даже с моим  poor English я не мог сдержать улыбку, слушая (и читая) диалоги и комментарии персонажей.

* Отличный сюжет. Он не пестрит сложными запутанными загадками и неожиданными поворотами, скорее, наоборот, все достаточно просто и предсказуемо. Да и большой продолжительностью он не может похвастаться, так что любители сериалов с запутанными сюжетами, когда друзья неожиданно становятся предателями, а враги - родственниками, тут лишь выскажут свое "фи", которое я не приму. Хороший сюжет не должен быть сложным и запутанным. Эта игра принесла мне массу удовольствия, заставила улыбаться, когда погиб главный злодей и мир был спасен. Эта игра позволила мне вернуться на мгновение в детство, когда я, смутившись, отвернулся во время поцелуя главного героя с возлюбленной (сам поцелуй не был порнографией, к которой мы и современные дети привыкли). В общем, сюжет я отнесу к сильной части игры, хоть здесь со мной многие не согласятся.

* Неплохие головоломки. Да, как заметил один из комментаторов, некоторые решения имеют странную логику, но от этого никуда не деться, игру делали такие же люди, как и мы. И мне кажется, что они полностью справились со своей задачей.

* ДУША.
Смотрел фильм "Кукольник" или "Кукловод", корейский. Сам фильм не важен, но там была такая фраза: Вкладывая в куклу душу, мы делаем ее живой.
Разумеется, я не точно процитировал, но, надеюсь, моя мысль понятна: в этой игре чувствуется душа. Люди, которые делали ее, вложили свою душу. Бездушные клепатели игр для масс не могут таким похвастаться, увы.



В заключение могу сказать, что игра не относится к тем, про которые можно сказать: Все должны поиграть! (хотя, а какие игры относятся?). Если вы любитель хороших игр, то она вас не должна разочаровать.

13062184.review: The Inner World is a hand-drawn point-and-click adventure game. The voice acting is very good, and the characters are very well written. The story is whimsical and silly and dramatic, suitable for both adults and children. The art is very cartoony and creative. The game shows hot spots when you press on the space bar, so there is no pixel hunting. The puzzles vary a lot from simple to devilishly hard. There is a very nice hint system if you get stuck. It is more fun to finish the puzzles without hints. Some of the puzzles are too hard for young children, so even though the story is child-appropriate, kids younger than 12 may get frustrated. The only drawback is that there is not enough variety in the music, some songs play over and over. I can recommend this game for fans of the point-and-click adventure genre.

12887585.review:
[b]the Inner World[/b] 13,99 €
[b]Point & Click Adventure von Headup Games & Studio Fizbin

bewertet werden Story, Soundtrack, Design 
[/b]

══►[b] Story [/b] 
Ein kleiner, unscheinbarer Junge namens Robert lebt in einer Welt tief in der Erde. Mit Luft wird diese Welt nur durch die drei Windbrunnen versorgt. 2 von ihnen sind schon vor langer Zeit erloschen. Der Letzte steht direkt vor dem Palast des Abt Conroy, einem alten, gemeinen Mann, welcher Robert vor langer Zeit adoptierte. Obwohl der Abt nicht besonders nett zu Robert ist, geht es ihm als Hofmusiker sehr gut. Bis er sich durch einen unglücklichen Zufall ausserhalb des Palastes wiederfindet und er erkennt, was für ein böser Mann der Abt Conroy ist...
[code]9 / 10 Punkte[/code]


══►[b] Soundtrack [/b] 
Die Geschichte von The Inner World wäre nur halb so schon wenn sie nicht ständig von tollen Soundtracks begleitet würde. Die Musik passt sich wunderbar an die Atmosphäre und die Eindrücke des Spiels an während die Vertonungen der Charaktere einen ganz eigenen, witzigen Charme haben. 
[code]10 / 10 Punkte[/code]


══►[b] Design [/b] 
Bei diesem Spiel ist ein scharfer 2D Grafikstil gewählt. Die einzelnen Texture lassen sich gut von Anderen unterscheiden. Manchmal kommt es allerdings zu kleineren Fehlern im Inventar oder im Spielmenü. Trotzdem ist das Design gelungen und angenehm an die Lage des Spielers angepasst.
[code]7 / 10 Punkte[/code]

11759693.review:
I don't get why the scores for this games aren't higher. Sure, I wouldn't say it's on par with the likes of Secret of Monkey Island, but I think it is fun to play all the way through (not stretched out), great humor, fine music and graphics and the puzzles are not outright evil, and if you get stuck there's a nice incremental hint system, that can be used instead of switching back and forth between the game and a browser every once in a while for someone who plays the game more for story than figuring out every single puzzle. 

I am a bit tired of the "humorous" sexism though (humour is a typical excuse for discrimination), mainly directed at Laura, not the least when you play as her. Many of the characters she interacts with objectify her, one insisting she must be a maid and unintelligent too and another one focused only on sexual interest. Robert doesn't respect her either. At one point in the game there's also a kiss between a woman and a man that happens that's basically sexual assault, and the kisser is even confronted with it, and her rejection was basically disregarded and he even says he doesn't regret doing it. Not cool, Headup Games & Studio Fizbin!

The other irritating problem I found was that the game crashed or got stuck on me every once in a while (maybe 7 times when I played through the entire game including all possible dialogue), but nothing that ruined the save, so it's not terrible. What does make this issue somewhat scary is that the game only creates a single save, so if it was hypothetically corrupted, there'd be no option but to start all over. I think a good solution for this problem - other than fixing the bugs - would be to create a save at the start of each chapter besides the current save which saves during a chapter too. This way one wouldn't have to start all over, and furthermore these saves will make getting all the achievements less of a pain.

Finally there's generally always two actions you can perform in the game, which for some reason are both mapped to a submenu when left-clicking, instead of mapping one to the left and right mouse button, which is a simple change that would definitely improve the UX in my opinion.

To sum up I definitely recommend this (mostly) very charming game!

Was ich weder positiv noch negativ bewerten möchte, ist die intigrierte Lösungshilfe. Gut, wenn man nicht weiter kommt ist diese sehr nützlich, jedoch auch sehr verlockend für faule Köpfchen.
Was ich wiederum positiv werte ist, dass man diese quasi nur Step-by-Step angezeigt bekommt. Nach dem Motto: "Mach zuerst das, dann sage ich dir wie es weiter geht".

Auch wenn der Hauptfokus auf Robert lag/liegt, hätte ich mir gewünscht, dass ich ein wenig mehr in Lauras Rolle schlüpfen könnte. Ich meine, es gab nur eine Frequenz / einen kleinen Part, in der ich als Laura spielen musste.

10259335.review:
After a longer time of abstinence I have returned to point-and-click adventures. I have been looking forward to playing The Inner World, I think, since I saw an interview with the developer some months ago. And The Inner World did not disappoint.

Nice cartoony graphics show a world that adds its own wildlife and mythology to everyday adventuring. The characters are lively and enjoyable but encounters are quite short. Still the main characters develop some depth.
Puzzles are mostly straightforward but if you sort of miss the beat it may take you a while to rediscover your puzzle-patterned mind set.

I played on an older machine so loading times between "rooms" was rather long, usually upward from 30 seconds. If it weren't for that I'd say you can play through the game in an hour, that is if you know what you're doing. Which you will when you replay for achievements or in order to write a walkthrough etc.
This touches on something I'm missing in the game. The game has three slots to each hold one progress of one playthrough. So you can never go back from some situation in the game. If you want to know how another decision at some point in the game would have played out you need to play the game from start up to that point again. This going forward is alright for a single playthrough but after the first I'd like to be able to jump to one of the five chapters at least.
On my second playthrough I forgot to change the handling of a situation, then realized it and played through almost four of five chapters again because I couldn't turn back time 30 seconds.

Anyway, the first playthrough makes for a number of enjoyable hours and I recommend The Inner World to players that want to spent some time on an easy-going, enchanting narrative about people, politics and impending doom ;)

Ein spaßiges Point'n Click Adventure, dass zwar keine neuen Maßstäbe setzt, aber dafür sehr solide Rätselkost abliefert. Leider ein wenig kurz, aber dafür auch kurzweilig. Viele Puzzle sind originell und das Setting ist einfach mal was komplett anderes. 
Man kann es sich etwa wie einen spielbaren Nicktoon ala "Rockos modernes Leben" vorstellen - soll heißen der Humor hat einen leicht bissigen Flair, der jedoch nie zynisch wird. Hier und da verbergen sich ein paar anrüchige Jokes die Kinder gar nicht schnallen werden, aber einen als Erwachsenen umso mehr zum schmunzeln bringen.
Die Handlung ist sehr stringend und simpel gestrickt, dabei aber interessant erzählt und mit viel Religionskritik gespickt. Wer sechs Stunden übrig hat, der kann ruhig mal mit Robert und Laura losziehen und die innere Welt erkunden.

9699270.review:
Ein wirklich schönes Point & Click Adventure - mit einigen Schwachstellen!

Die meisten Dialoge und die Synchronisation sind wirklich gelungen und die Story ist auch ganz schön (wenn man auch teilweise das Gefühl hat, dass sie nicht ganz ausgereift ist). Ich mag im Comic-Stil gezeichnete P&C-Adventures (wie "Edna bricht aus", "Deponia" usw. und nun auch "The inner World").

Es gibt einige witzige und interessante Charaktere, die man im Laufe des Spiels kennenlernt. Leider finde ich, dass hier häufig das Potenzial nicht ausgschöpft wurde, denn viele Charaktere hätten einen etwas größeren Auftritt verdient.

Leider ist das Spiel recht kurz und die Welt erscheint einem sehr klein. Wenn man ein neues Bild betritt lädt das Spiel sehr lange, was echt nerven kann, wenn man öfters mal hin und herlaufen will/muss.
Einige Parts in den Dialogen widerholen sich immer wieder und man redet häufig über Dinge, die im weiteren Spielverlauf gar keine Bedeutung mehr haben, was ich sehr schade fand. Dennoch sind die Dialoge sehr schön geschrieben und haben einen netten Humor.

Einige haben das Problem, dass Robert sehr langsam läuft. Das Problem hatte ich auch. Eine Problemlösung kann man hier im Forum finden. Was mich neben den langen Ladezeiten echt genervt hat ist, dass ich oft Gegenstände auf etwas anwenden wollte und sie per Drag&Drop rübergezogen habe (eigentlich kein schlechtes System), sie dann aber nicht erkannt wurden. Dies kam irgendwie besonders ab dem 3. Kapiten vor. (Dadurch sind mir scheinbar auch einige Errungenschaften durch die Lappen gegangen..)
Schöne wäre es, wenn man das Spiel auch selbtständig speichern könnte...allerdings war ich irgendwann echt froh, dass das Spiel ständig speichert, weil es leider doch ein paar Mal abgestürzt ist. 

Trotzdem ist "The Inner World" ein nettes Point&Click-Adventure und wer Fan solcher Spiele ist und nach einem neuen Spiel sucht, sollte hier definitiv mal reinschauen ;)

(Ich hab das Spiel übrigens natürlich komplett von Anfang bis Ende durchgespielt, allerdings im Offline-Modus da mein Internet nicht funktioniert hat, deshalb steht hier, dass ich es noch nicht wirklich gespielt hätte von den Minuten her ;))

9294029.review:
The Inner World has all the makings of an excellent adventure game. The animations are fluid and clean, the characters are likable, the music is charming, and the story is interesting. The embedded hint system comes in handy when you get stuck on puzzles, making it easy to get help without breaking the flow of the game (and having to alt+tab out to look something up.)

Highly recommended, I enjoyed this about as much as Machinarium - a game recently renowned in the genre. Do yourself a favor and pick this up.

9236488.review: Как мне кажется, в игре не просто много лишней болтовни (бла-бла-бла ни о чём), а МЕГАпросто уйма диалогов, которые абсолютно не связаны с сюжетом и ни как не влияют на игровые ситуации. Таким образом, коротенький квестик раздули в 4 раза, за счёт бездарных и глупых диалогов.

9209959.review:
Если рисованные квесты со своими уникальными мирами, вам интересны, не обходите эту игру стороной. При знакомстве с игрой сразу бросается в глаза оригинальный мир Аспозии, и напрашивается сравнение с играми от другого немецкого производителя, и неожиданно, эта игра ни в чём не уступает своим более известным аналогам. Сюжет конечно чудаковат, но зато хорошо проработан и интересен. Персонажи все яркие, каждый со своими тараканами. Особенно интересно наблюдать за двумя главными персонажами, поиграть, кстати, дадут за обоих. Задачек особо сложных и не логичных тут вы не встретите. Юмор в этой игре немного странный, во-первых он совсем не детский, а во-вторых в нём постоянно царят нотки феминизма, но вписано в сюжет всё очень органично. Из недостатков отмечу лишь то, что переходы между локациями ознаменуются загрузочными экранами, неприятная мелочь. В заключение, хочется пожелать команде разработчиков не останавливаться и продолжать в том же духе!
p.s. Игра вышла без локализации на русский язык, но была полностью переведена энтузиастами, найти его в сети не составит труда, в крайнем случае, обращайтесь.

9187296.review:
"It seems like Europe is the place to go for point-and-click games lately. From Daedalic’s awesome Deponia series, to newer entries like The Journey Down, Europe has been keeping the genre alive in both quantity and quality. Studio Fizbin looks to keep this trend going with their game, The Inner World. They’ve done their best to create a comical world with a simple-but-endearing art style. With plenty of puzzles, voice-acting, and interactions, Studio Fizbin may have a hit on their hands. The game has an innovative hint system and deals with some fairly mature themes for the genre. Do these aspects of the game lead to a winning breeze, or is it just a lot of hot air?"

Full review at http://www.hbhud.com/2013/10/22/review-of-the-inner-world/

9175675.review:
Having not played this kind of game in a long time, it aggravated me how long it took to get to the next part of the story sometimes - and I swear I tried Macguyvering everything! That being said, this was an interesting game. I liked the unique art style. The voice acting was all right - Robert's was probably the best. You could tell at times that Laura's intonations weren't quite right, though, which I found odd. Also, the mixture of American and UK accents was confusing at times, but for the sake of the story I let it go. Favorite character: the garbage dealer. 

It's a short game, and could have used a bit of tinkering to make it into a great final vision. I recommend you get this game if it's on sale, otherwise don't pay full price.

9136160.review:
¿Que tenemos hoy? Pues tenemos una aventura gráfica "nivel Paint", aunque los fondos están algo más trabajados, pero no importa, es bastante divertida. El tono es humorístico, así que las conversaciones se hacen amenas. El sonido es puramente ambiental. El equivalente a la música de ascensor pero en videojuego. Durante el juego usa bastante algo que muchas aventuras sólo usan pocas veces, que es combinar varios objetos de tu inventario entre sí. Puede parecer que esto lo complica, pero realmente el juego es facilón.
Todo esto que estoy contando parece que describa a una buena aventura gráfica que te hará pasar un rato divertido pero... ¡alto! El juego tiene un bug. En el último capítulo, si haces ciertas acciones en el orden no prefijado, desaparece de tu inventario un pájaro que necesitas casi al final del capítulo, entonces te quedas bloqueado sin nada que hacer. Estas cosas me tocan mucho las pelotas, y por lo tanto, desaconsejo el juego. Si corrigiesen el problema en el futuro, cambiaría mi veredicto, pero mientras tanto, vender juegos con fallos donde te quedas bloqueado debería ser delito con penas de expulsión de la Vía Láctea.

[b]Vale, entonces... ¿no se puede hacer nada?[/b] Sí que se puede, que es descargar una partida guardada y continuar a partir de ella, si te quedas atascado. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/251430/discussions/0/792924952557885445/] Aquí[/url] puedes hacerlo.
[b]Entonces, si el juego no tuviera ese fallo, ¿qué te parecería?[/b] Un juego chachi piruli.
[b]¿Mandamos unos sicarios a por los programadores?[/b] No, intentaremos sobrellevar la vida con este fallo sin necesidad de cometer el crimen.

8420552.review:
This is a cute, all-ages-friendly, point and click adventure game. The main character leaves his home as the naive protagonist and must work his way up to becoming the hero, along with the help of his friend Laura and her pet pigeon. 

This is one of those adventure games where it's got a few cute, unique elements, but also it's more like a comic book you can play through. The puzzles are set up in a usual adventure game style, where you have to find and combine some items to make them work. 

I'll warn you that it's a bit dialog heavy. You have to talk to a lot of characters, so if you're not in the mood to sit through quite a bit of worldbuilding-through-chatting, I'd wait to play this game until you feel more patient. 

It's not a revolutionary game, but it is fun. I'm happy to have it in my library. The only bad thing is there was one, single puzzle that was impossible for me to solve, because I had already tried that combination of things, but not at the right exact time. Regular adventure game frustrations, you know? It could really have been fixed, I think, but it doesn't ruin the entire game. The thing is, once you talk to someone and they give you all the information they can, or they have said all there is to say in a conversation, that button gets grayed out. You can click it again, but throughout the entire game the character would just repeat the same thing over if you did so. That caused a problem with one of the puzzles. 

Other than that minor issue, I enjoyed playing this, I found the characters cute (if not a little cliche), and it had some lovely art and a nice world.

7935476.review:
So hat ein klassisches Point-&-Click-Adventure auszusehen.

The Inner World ist ein weiterer gelungener Beitrag des mächtigen LucasArts-Erbes, der euch sichtlich mit Fairness und Cleverness begeistern möchte. Obwohl der Titel weit von einem Epos entfernt ist, bin ich erstaunt von der Rundheit des Gesamtwerks, von der nahezu perfekten Balance des Schwierigkeitsgrades und der Entwicklung der Geschichte. In The Inner World fühlt sich der Anfang wie ein Anfang und das Ende wie ein Ende an - im Gegensatz zu beispielsweise den Daedalic-Titeln, die dies trotz ihrer hohen Qualität nicht schaffen. Zentrale Ereignisse werden mit wenigen, aber treffenden Sätzen abgehakt, während Fans des Schwafelns in den vielen optionalen sowie witzig geschriebenen Dialogen auf ihre Kosten kommen. Wenn Robert das gleiche Charisma besitzen würde wie Sidekick Laura, dann wäre ein Vergleich mit Edna bricht aus gerechtfertigt gewesen. Und wir wissen alle, welche Auswirkungen dieser Überraschungserfolg hatte.

 Andreas Altenheimer

7918639.review:
The Inner World is a 2D point-and-click adventure game and I have to say that I expected a bit more from it. There weren't any major flaws, but most things in the game felt very average.

The graphic style is probably the best thing about the game. The backgrounds are very detailed, but the same can't be said about the characters. The characters don't quite seem to fit in the world. But that's a very minor thing compared to the other issues the game has.

The main character, Robert, is an apprentice to a wind monk. He is quite naïve and goofy. The other character you get to play as is Laura, who is a thief. She seemed quite grumpy and had this "whatever" attitude. So they're not the most likable characters.

The game starts with some backstory of the world and events that lead to it's current state. After that Robert is seen polishing his master's amulet, which then gets stolen by pigeon called Peck. Peck escapes through a trash chute and Robert follows with the intention of catching Peck and getting the amulet back. The story then develops into a pretty normal point-and-click story about saving the world. After the first chapter I already knew what was going to happen in the end, because I'm pretty sure I've played game or watched a movie with a very similar plot. And it was really obvious how to story would go on after chapter 1.

The store page lists screamingly funny dialogues as a feature in the game, but I didn't find the dialogue funny. It was quite boring to be honest. Could be that the funny dialogue was lost in translation, since this is a German game and I played it in English. The dialogue certainly wasn't helped by the voice acting, which ranged from bad to decent. In the end there was this "emotional" part in the story and the voice acting seemed like the actors were just reading their lines out loud. There was no emotion whatsoever.

The puzzles in this game are also a mixed bag. Some were fairly easy to figure out while some were pretty illogical and basically required trying all possible items in order to solve them. Some items, that seemed fairly logical for solving the puzzles, didn't work and the item needed to solve the puzzle didn't always seem like they'd be a natural choice. The puzzles also required a bit of guessing. There is a hint system in the game, but it's optional and I didn't use it on my playthrough.

I had a couple of weird glitches where the character would just walk to where I pointed him/her and stop and not complete the action he/she was supposed to do. After waiting for a minute or so, the character would finally do what it was supposed to do. On a second playthrough I did to get all the achievements I missed the game also crashed to desktop twice.

To sum it up, The Inner World is an average point-and-click adventure with not much going for it. I beat the game in 5-6 hours, so it isn't very long. Some of the puzzles are quite frustrating and require some guesswork. The story wasn't anything special or new either to make me recommend the game. Unless you're a big fan of point-and-clicks, I don't recommend playing this one, since there are better point-and-clicks out there.

The Inner World ci terrà ottima compagnia per circa sei orette, ora più ora meno a seconda della vostra capacità di mangiare enigmi. Lo sapete, io sono un romanticone, ma non mollavo una lacrimuccia alla fine di un titolo dai tempi di The Walking Dead. Una frase in particolare è riuscita a commuovermi, ma non posso diverla qui per ovvi motivi.

Insomma, non posso che consigliarvi questo titolo, sopratutto se siete in carenza di avventure grafiche. Un universo di gioco originale come pochi, una trama ben scritta e personaggi ben caratterizzati, uniti ad un prezzo più che giusto e, per i fanatici, una ventina di achievement da sbloccare rendono The Inner World un gioco che merita i vostri soldi fino all’ultimo centesimo. 7782437.review:
Der Stil erinnert stark an Walther Moer, dessen Bücher sehr „fabelhaft“ sind. Bekannt ist vor allem „Käpt‘n Blaubär“. In „The inner World“ trifft man auf zahlreiche, seltsame Gestalten. Robert ist der Hauptcharakter, ein unglaublich naiver, kleiner Bursche mit einer Flötennase. Er wächst bei Conroy, einem Windmönch auf, der über Asposien herrscht. Die „innere Welt“ wird von Basylen (eine Art „Drache“) bedroht, die ungehorsame Bewohner versteinern. Conroy ist der einzige der die Basylen beruhigen kann, das nutzt der Kerl für seinen Vorteil aus. Das Conroy Dreck am Stecken hat, ist sonnenklar. Außer für Robert. Die fast schon unfassbare Naivität von Robert, wirkt aber nicht aufgesetzt, wie manche Magazine den Spiel rot ankreiden. Er ist halt in einem „Elfenbeinturm“ groß geworden und kennt nichts von der Welt. Gerade deshalb ist er als Hauptcharakter hervorragend geeignet, um den Spieler an diese wundersame Welt mit Wollmäusen, Schrofs, Flötennasen, Basylen, Fosfos und vielen mehr, heranzuführen. 
Davon abgesehen sorgt seine naive Art und simple Denkweise, immer wieder für Lacher. Das Abenteuer kommt durch die Taube „Hack“ ins rollen, die ein Amulett von Conroy stiehlt. Robert fühlt sich verantwortlich und will das Amulett zurückholen. Conroy passt das gar nicht, er kann ihn aber nicht mehr rechtzeitig stoppen. Auf der Suche nach der Taube, trifft Robert auf Laura, eine Rebellin. Im weiteren Spielverlauf darf man sie ebenfalls ab und zu steuern. Laura bildet hier einen schönen Kontrast zu Robert, sie ist nämlich ganz schön „zickig“, dafür aber wesentlich aufgeklärter als Robert. 
Schöne, hochaufgelöste Hintergründe mit zahlreichen Animationen sorgen für eine stimmige Welt. Die Synchronisation ist spitze, ein Extra-Lob verdient hier der Sprecher vom Schrof (vor allem diese Lache). Ein bitte, was? Ein Schrof. Er ist das tödlichste Tier in Asposien, da sein Körper zu 96% aus Gift besteht. Meistens hockt er auf einen Stein, da er nicht über den Boden laufen kann, da seine Krallen ansonsten alles weg ätzen würden. Was meistens dazu führt, das er stecken bleibt.
Das einzige was noch giftiger ist als der Schrof, ist das Weibchen der Gattung. Eine Schrofline. Herrlich als sich Laura und eine Schrofline gegenseitig angiften und der arme Robert, zwischen die Fronten gerät. Die Wollmäuse sind wirklich niedlich und bestehen wie der Name schon sagt, hauptsächlich aus Wolle. Deshalb fliegen sie oft in der Gegend herum. Die Fosfos sind in Asposien wichtige Tiere, da sie Licht spenden. Im Erdinneren nicht gerade unwichtig. Sie sehen aus wie klassische Bettlaken-Gespenster. Doch es werden immer weniger. Der Wind, die wichtigste Energiequelle in Asposien ist ebenfalls fast verschwunden. Was geht hier vor? Was für eine Rolle spielen hier die Basylen? Und vor allem: Was hat Conroy angestellt? Robert und Laura gehen diesen Geheimnissen auf die Spur. Die Rätsel sind größtenteils klassisch. Sprich: Dialog und Kombinationsrätsel. Die Logik wird dabei einige Male arg strapaziert. Geht aber im Großen und Ganzen in Ordnung. Die Steuerung geht leicht von der Hand, klassisches Point&Click, wie man es liebt.

Fazit: Was für ein schönes Adventure. Für Walther Moer Fans ein Muss. Der Rest darf aber auch gerne zugreifen. Mit Deponia das witzigste Adventure in diesem Jahr. Hochauflösende Hintergründe, einfaches Point&Click, keinerlei Bugs, gutes Rätseldesign und vor allem sehr liebenswerte Charaktere. Adventure-Herz, was willst du mehr?

7493969.review:
Do you like point-n-clicks? Then find the time/money to get this game, period.

The Inner World combines a beautiful and intriguing graphical style with some wonderfully off the wall design, such as a world built on the inside of a sphere, not the outside like ours. This is all backed with a melodic and inquisitive musical score that binds it all together (I could happily listen to the opening menu music for quite some time). The human-like inhabitants all have stripey arms, legs and nose, apart from the main character Robert, who seems different from everyone else with his flute nose.

The adventure starts with Robert going on a quick errand to rescue a necklace stolen by a pesky pigeon but he quickly finds himself being sucked into an adventure to discover the many secrets of the Inner World; which is a lot as he's never left the castle before!

Through his journey you meet a wealth of very original characters and combined with the delightfully naive Robert lead to some great writing with a nice dry sense of humour. The voice acting and translation in itself is superb considering that the game was written in German and any slip ups are almost unnoticeable.

The mandatory puzzles are also top class, encouraging you to explore and use that point-n-click crazy logic to allow you to progress. Many of these give Robert and the other characters a great opportunity to make you smile, particularly Laura the female lead. There is also a robust hint system for those that find this kind of game a bit too much of a challenge so you never feel held back from enjoying the story.

Completed this in 7 or 8 hours or so but enjoyed every second. A wonderful world with great characters to fall in love with.

7439196.review:
A quirky cartoonish adventure game in the classic adventure game style.

Backgrounds are lovely, Character Art is cartoonish but nice. Voice Acting is great and generally Sound is good. Writing is interesting and the dialogue is delightfully "oddball". 

Keep in mind the bizarre nature of the puzzles will require equally bizarre solutions. "Pixel hunt" & "Item Clutter" is never really an issue (hold Spacebar for hotspots). So yeah, you can brute force your way through quite a bit. The hint system is good because it will give you clues (more specific each subsequent time when used on the same puzzle), and doesn't just hand out answers.

This is a quality game at a reasonable price. What isn't to love about this?

7362356.review:
As modern point and click adventure games go, this one is fairly decent. It's not a mind-blowing experience by any means, but it's definitely not bad either. You play as a guy named Robert who finds himself thrust into a quest to save the world (naturally). Robert is a very naive and unassuming sort of fella, so a lot of the plot and humor centers around his clueless innocence. The story and dialogue is fairly good for the most part, in turns charming, funny and dark. The voice acting is hit or miss, though - mostly it is decent, but a few lines here and there are inexplicably bad (wrong pronunciations, improper emphasis of words, etc). Mechanically, the game also has its ups and downs. Being a point and click game, you would think that the pointing and clicking would be spot-on, but that's not always the case. Sometimes you can't click on things that you should be able to click (though it usually fixes itself in a second or two). Additionally, half of the achievements don't seem to be working properly. However, the developers have started to release patches to fix some of these problems, so a lot of these things may not be issues in the future. Regardless, none of these faults are deal breakers by any means, anyways. 

The puzzles are fairly standard in adventure game terms. You basically just go around talking to people, picking up objects, and using those objects (or combinations thereof) to solve puzzles and progress further. Thankfully, none of the solutions are overly ridiculous or unintuitive (as is the case with many adventure games), though you will need to really think some stuff through from time to time. Apparently there is also a help system in place if you need it (which I didn't even realize until after finishing the game), so you probably won't ever get stuck for long, if you even get stuck at all. The game is divided into 5 chapters, each of which consists of a self-contained series of puzzles that take place on 3 or 4 "screens". Playtime is probably around 7-8 hours or so, give or take. So keep that in mind in terms of how much you are willing to pay. All in all, the game is pretty good. As I said earlier, it is nothing mind-blowing for the genre, but it's a nice experience while it lasts. Probably the worst thing I could say about it (aside from the minor glitches noted above) is that the pacing is very slow. The dialogue in particular seems like it takes foreeeeeeeever sometimes, especially with a main character who is so low-key and slow. The pace may test your patience at times. But if you don't mind that and are into classic adventure games, this is probably worth a look at some point. I would probably recommend waiting for a sale, though, unless you are hardcore into adventure games and need something new to play now.

39497449.review:
[h1]Hintergrundgeschichte:[/h1]
The Inner World handelt von der Geschichte des Protagonisten Robert, der im Weltinneren bei seinem "Ziehvater" aufwächst. Durch Zufall stellt sich heraus, dass Roberts Ziehvater Grund für das Versiegen der lebenswichtigen Windbrunnen ist. Nun liegt es an Robert und seiner rebellischen Begleitung Laura, den Wind zurück in die Inner World zu bringen.

[h1]Steuerung:[/h1]
Wie in jedem anderen Point&Click-Adventure auch: linke und rechte Maustaste sowie ggf. die Leertaste.

[h1]Gestaltung und Ton:[/h1]
Wieder ein wunderbar gezeichnetes, Märchen-ähnliches Abenteuer, dass mit liebevollen Details überzeugt. Den Kulissen und vor allem der Geschichte wurde die Hintergrundmusik angepasst und die Stimmen passen zu den Charakteren. Man merkt die Mühe, die von den Machern in das Spiel gesteckt wurde.

[h1]Sprache:[/h1]
Ich habe das Spiel auf Deutsch gespielt, allerdings gibt es in den Sprachoptionen die Möglichkeit auf Englisch, Französisch etc. umzustellen. Also alles wie Spieler es von Daedalic gewöhnt sind.

[h1]Schwierigkeitsgrad:[/h1]
Einfach bis mittelschwer. Viele Herausforderungen gab es nicht und die Geschichtshandlung ist sehr geradlinig.

[h1]Achievements:[/h1]
Überwiegend basieren die Achievements auf der Hauptgeschichte. Einige lassen sich verpassen, also ruhig alles und jeden ansprechen/angucken, da man nur einen Savepoint machen kann und bei verpassten Achievements das gesamte Spiel wiederholen müsste :)

[h1]Technisches:[/h1]
Bei mir sind keine technischen Probleme aufgetreten (Windows 7, etwas älterer Computer)

[h1]Mein Fazit:[/h1]
Eine erfrischend neue Geschichte, die das Potential für ein gutes Märchen abliefert. Ich habe es genossen, die wieder liebevoll gestalteten Charaktere und die beeindruckenden Hintergrundkulissen zu betrachten. Ich würde es allen Daedalic-begeisterten Spielern empfehlen, darüber hinaus besonders Kindern mit ihren Eltern zusammen.

39464439.review: Very cute and endearing point and click game

39498275.review:
The Inner World sat on my shelf for a long time before I got around to playing it. Of all the point-and-click adventure games I've played in that time I will rank this second to Night of the Rabbit. You play as Robert, a young "Asposian" (with a flute for a nose) living in the Inner World (a sort of hollow Earth theory) and stuck in a sheltered life of lies and deception. His master Conroy has taken control of Asposia and kept Robert an unwitting prisoner. Naive and trusting, Robert sets off on his own to find out the real truth put and end to Conory's plot.

With lovely hand-drawn animation this video games feels like an 80s CITV show that you are in control of. Something about adventure games that usually bugs me is the constant going back and forth between long distances to reach new areas but the Inner World keeps everything tight and close. The environments feel cosy and are nicely detailed and the puzzles are just the right level of difficulty.

Spread across 5 chapters, I finished this game in 4.5 hours, winning all but 2 of the 23 trophies/achievements and grabbing all of the trading cards. The physical copy comes with the soundtrack in MP3 form on the disc as well as a postcard and a sticker of Peck (which I stuck to the side of my computer). There is another edition that features a lot more than this, but I believe it was limited and thus unavailable.

It seems that the game has been successful across all platforms and has spawned a sequel. Perhaps this is the beginning of a popular series. We shall see. Either way, it is worth your time if you into this sort of game.
